148398920.review:
Strider – a reboot of the SEGA game from the nineties, with lightning fast action which requires equally fast reactions. This means I haven’t been able to finish it and I got super frustrated, just like with all the games of this type.
The graphics are stylized and very nice to look at. There is also a barely visible sort of vertical grid, which I guess is included to be reminiscent of the old console games and the screens they were played on. Other than that, the basic enemies all look similar, with a few exceptions, such as elite soldiers, bugs, and giant robots. 
The backgrounds in some levels are impressive, I have to say, and give the impression that you are playing a level in a much bigger world than the game really has. The sound is satisfying as well. Hits and slashes sound good, and so do the death screams of defeated enemies. The music is appropriately epic, but nothing too spectacular.
The gameplay is, like I’ve mentioned, quite fast, but the game introduces it in increments. When you begin, you can only jump and attack at close range. As the game progresses, you unlock the slide, double jump, dash, range attacks, and all the other moves which are the staple of action platformers.
In no part of the game do you feel bored, but there are a few major problems with the game that made me rage quit a few times. First, the game starts off too easy. It literally takes one hit to kill most enemies, which lulls you into a false state of safety. 
As you progress, however, this starts to change quite a bit. The enemies become more resilient, armored, and shielded, their weapons become overpowered (plasma rifles, I’m looking at you), their behavior becomes too annoying (those damn bugs!), and the game itself is pretty much impossible by the end, when you are in the elevator and the enemies just pile up on you. Perhaps this is just due to me being bad at these types of games, which is a possibility I’m not denying.
The boss fights, paradoxically, are almost not hard at all. Once you get the pattern down, they just become exercises in following their movement and avoiding the attacks. The animations are fun to look at, at least, and the bosses are all quite different, each with their own strengths and weaknesses, and sometimes even fun to fight. All, except for the Gravitron. That thing can go die with other annoying game bosses.
The story is ludicrous, but befitting a game that was created at a time when an Italian plumber jumping on mushrooms was an acceptable plot. The titular Strider is a typical manga ninja cyber assassin, who holds his sword behind his back when running. He has the task of eliminating Grandmaster Meio, the ruler of Kazakh, an evil country that is totally not Soviet Russia. You will fight, among others, a mad and eccentric scientist, four martial arts ladies with huge thighs, and a general who wears a fur hat on his bearded head, talks with a thick accent, and runs around on robot raptor legs. If that is not enough to entertain you, I don’t know what might.
One thing that this game succeeds is actually making you feel like a ninja. You’ll do a double jump and dash to grab hold of the underside of a platform with your daggers. Then you’ll jump up, slice the enemy in two, and slide into a ventilation shaft. On the other side, a flying machine will try to attack you, but not before you throw shurikens at it, and use your sword to deflect the laser from the turret. The game is full of moments like these.
All in all, Strider is a fun, albeit increasingly hard game, that verges on impossible for me. It had some really intense and interesting moments, and it had me screaming and cursing as well. If you like these kinds of games, and you excel under pressure, go play Strider, and be a ninja cyber assassin who saves the world from an evil Grandmaster and his lackeys.

[h1]𝕋𝕙𝕖 𝕝𝕖𝕘𝕖𝕟𝕕𝕒𝕣𝕪 𝕊𝕥𝕣𝕚𝕕𝕖𝕣 𝕒𝕤𝕤𝕒𝕦𝕝𝕥𝕤 ℝ𝕦𝕤𝕤𝕚𝕒 𝕥𝕙𝕚𝕤 𝕥𝕚𝕞𝕖... 𝔸𝕗𝕥𝕖𝕣 𝕙𝕖 𝕨𝕒𝕤 𝕕𝕠𝕟𝕖, 𝕠𝕟𝕝𝕪 𝕒 𝕤𝕡𝕒𝕣𝕜 𝕠𝕗 𝕙𝕚𝕤 𝕗𝕝𝕠𝕒𝕥𝕚𝕟𝕘 𝕣𝕖𝕕 𝕤𝕔𝕒𝕣𝕗 𝕣𝕖𝕞𝕒𝕚𝕟𝕖𝕕![/h1]

If you've played any Capcom Vs game before, you'd know who Strider is... Adept of Ninjitsu, master of swords, vanquisher of evil AND foiler of masterminds.

Welcome to Khazakh, where Strider is sent to investigate some sort of dictatorship. What he finds, however, are plenty of soldiers to cut in half, as well as flying robots that Strider can parry and deflect their bullets into them, annahilating them instantly. Strider is kind of... ruthless like that.

Strider is an amazing, PERFECT platformer. There is absolutely nothing bad I can say about this game, other than how difficult they've made backtracking to find missed collectibles. Strider is very rapid, and his sword play is even quicker. After defeating certain cringe bosses, Strider uncovers his lost tools in the city of Khazakh, Eagle Option especially is very useful to get rid of mobs quickly and effortlessly. Strider can also climb unto walls and later, FLY! You've heard me, Strider can fly, so if you feel bored at first, I advise you to keep playing.

Strider is [b]9.5/10[/b] platformer goodness. Its quick action bossfights are very memorable, and you feel like you are in there saving the Russians in Khazakh, that have willingly given into oppression and become slaves... Sigh!

142815995.review:
Well, I'll start from the beginning. I first discovered Strider Hiryu in Marvel vs. Capcom for Playstation, and thought the character was really cool. The more I played as him, the more I felt I had to have more. From there, I got the NES and Genesis versions, and I really started to dive into the lore. After that I played an emulation of the arcade version, and then in December 2022 I bought the 2014 Strider, and I firmly believe that this is truly what Strider was always meant to be, without any constraints or limitations, just pure, heart-pounding action from start to finish, but still with an underlying story that is sparse enough so as not to interrupt the action, but present enough that you don't lose sight of the ultimate goal. 

     And there really is nothing quite like running at top speed on the first stage, just slashing non-stop and effortlessly blowing through any enemy foolish enough to stand in a Strider's way.

     In addition, the story is just vague enough that it can bring players together in discussions about different theories and fan fiction, but still present enough that you don't lose sight of the ultimate goal. There is even a slew of collectibles to add to the gameplay experience and challenge the player, especially in the Research Facility. Not only do they offer a challenge, but a reward; the Fallen Striders give Hiryu excellent changes in color palette to suit many different tastes, and the enemy and story intel expand upon the world and story of the game for those, like me, who want to know more about the amazing world that Capcom and Double Helix have created. 

     Another excellent aspect of Strider is all of the callbacks and easter eggs from the old games, and beyond their mere presence, that they actually tie in to the story of the game and make sense and are explained therein, rather than being just for the sake of nostalgia like so many other games of today.

  And, although this as gone on far too long already, I just end this review without talking about the gameplay. The pace and speed of the gameplay, combined with the sheer multitude and variety of enemies, the well crafted and inventive boss fights, and the mass of upgrades, abilities, and attacks available to Hiryu, this game makes for one of the best gaming experiences that I have ever had. The 2014 Strider will forever live in my heart as one of my favorite video games of all time. In fact, this game is the entire reason that I began PC gaming and am currently on Steam! So thanks Strider!

Well, if you actually made it through this whole thing, thanks for reading!
I'm gonna consider this my tribute to my favorite character of all time!
TAKE ME TO YOUR BOSS!

Oh, by the way, I'm a fan of Strider! Hahaha!

ROCK ON, everybody!

141734197.review:
Note: Big edit after the dotted line. I didn't want to take out what I said....but I wanted to update it after more play:

note 2: Another big dotted line. TL;DR If you can't be bothered to fix your game from crashing, you get an instant thumbs down:

Strider is always a special series to me. I first saw it in the arcade and it looked amazing. Then I tried the NES version when that came out. This is where my love for the series began...and I really mean love. Strider on NES is one of my favorite games on that system and probably the game I have beaten the most in my life. I had everything memorized, down to where every file would drop on the screen. It still is an amazing game.

Strider Returns was awful (but that really isn't part of the series anyway) and Strider 2 was good enough to get a couple playthroughs. That brings us to this one.

This Strider feels like if the arcade and NES versions were merged, with the more current technology. You can call it a Metroidvania if you want...but it still feels more stage like to me. Hiryu has more access to climb everywhere, and the levels can be pretty big. It checks all the boxes just right for what a Strider game should be: crazy cypher swinging action, interesting bosses, exploration, and climbing walls and ceilings. Everything is just right.

Sounds promising right? So why the thumbs down on a series I really love? Because it is missing something major.

Strider has no heart.

It really feels like the developers wanted to make it Strider, so they incorporated everything that needs to be into it properly...they just didn't put that love into it to make it good. The areas look nice but turn out to be boring. The enemies are traditional good, but uninteresting. Climbing everywhere becomes a chore. The map is functional, but is bare bones and a little confusing. The power ups are so-so. There is noting I can say is missing in the design, but it just not good design. I mean, it might as well be a Spiderman game....it would check all the right boxes for that too, but nothing convinces me it was designed to be strictly Strider.

Its a shame because I absolutely love the Strider series....but this? I'd rather go back and play the NES version for the 1,000th time. 

This Strider..the body is here in complete form. But it feels dead inside.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Here comes the edited section, and everything above couldn't be more wrong. The problem was that I didn't understand the game like I thought I did when writing this review.

Because of the adventure style, I was treating it too much like a hybrid of the arcade and NES version.  I wasn't focusing on exploring the areas like I should have. And I wasn't using my map. Not using my map was the big problem. I expected this to be a little more straight forward level-by-level. 

Its not. There is backtracking and searching around needed. It isn't really "Metroidvania", but it has aspects of those style of games. 

I do stand by the enemies being boring, but the combat gets pretty crazy. I also stand by the Spiderman comment, but it doesn't bother me as much as I get more into the exploring side.....not being in such a rush to get to "the next level" or so I thought.

This game has stepped up dramatically in my opinion once I knew what I was actually supposed to be doing.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Now for the third part:

I got to a section where I have to fight a boss. There is no way to save on the way, and it took me a good amount of time to get to the boss. Mid fight, dialogue came up and the game froze and then crashed. This is the 4th crash I have had, and the most annoying.

I loaded it up again, and started my path to the boss. Getting halfway (and through the harder parts to get to him), it froze and crashed again.

No sympathy: if you don't fix it, you don't deserve a recommendation. I think i will go back to the NES version.

140606266.review:
[b]TLDR: Cool 2.5D Metroidvania with tight, responsive controls; somewhat unbalanced combat but not frustratingly so, though it's somewhat easy; pretty good graphics, passable music, cheap price, it's pretty good.
THAT SAID THERE IS A BUG WITH THIS RELEASE THAT CAN PREVENT IT FROM LAUNCHING, CHECK THE BOTTOM OF THE REVIEW ON HOW TO FIX IT[/b]


[b]Strider[/b] is a 2014 reboot of the old... Strider games. Those slash-em-up platformers that debuted on the arcade, got ONE sequel and then dropped off the face of the planet (outside of the main guy appearing in MvC).
I KNOW Capcom has a... [i]reputation[/i] for doing edgy gritty reboots in this era that would get nowhere and just kinda suck in general. You might think this is one of those considering it never got followed up on.
[b]But no, it's actually pretty damn good.[/b]


It's a 2.5D Metroidvania. The original games were linear platformers, this one sorta expands the formula into a full-on open map that you explore as you get more abilities.
Your moveset is also a REALLY good expansion on both the original games and the protagonist's MvC appearances; you have directional slashes, that come out INSTANTLY and can be done as fast as you can mash the button (you can attack as lightspeed like a funny ninja).
You also have doublejumping, a slide kick, a stomp attack, a [b]launcher attack[/b] (!!!) that lets you [I]juggle enemies[/i] (this is not at all necessary to do, it's just for flair), 4 different elemental variants of your blade with different effects each, and an aimable dash that can be done in any direction and has special effects depending on your weapon.

Now, it might just be the Sonic PTSD kicking in, but I'm at a point where I'll go into 3D/2.5D games EXPECTING the controls to be floaty, stilted, jerky and delayed. It's like a staple of 3D at this point, main characters that are janky physics objects that lock up your controls for multiple frames while figuring out what to do.
[b]But I'm happy to say this game controls DAMN well for what it is.[/b] Your attacks and inputs are recognized INSTANTLY, and your movement is as tight as it gets. You can maneuver in mid-air to your heart's content like you would in a Megaman game, and your airdash (once you unlock it) gives you some CRAZY aerial mobility on top of that. It's [i]tight[/i].


...That said though, the combat is kind of... not balanced all that well?
Enemies can and will shoot bursts of bullets with no telegraphing, but you take VERY low damage from most things. Like the game doesn't EXPECT you to avoid attacks, so you'll be eating stray bullets a lot.
Weapons are also not really all that well balanced, with the fire and gravity swords really OUTCLASSING the other two by a long margin. Fire deals a ridiculous amount of damage per swing, and gravity extends your reach with boomerang projectiles (at the cost of slightly limiting your attack speed by 2 projectiles on screen at a time).
You compare this with two lower damage swords, one of which reflects projectiles (useful, but not needed since you take so little damage) with the other one freezing enemies (not so useful, still low damage, frozen enemies block your path).

Bosses are also kinda hard to make out on a first run, with weird attack patterns with little telegraphing that aren't very intuitive to figure out just LOOKING at them. You'll figure it out if you pay a bit of attention but again, it's rough on your first time.

Honestly my BIGGEST gripe with the game overall is the level design.
Or rather, not the level design ITSELF but [b]the lack of PROPER fast travel or warping[/b].
Almost every area has warp spots laid throughout that (once you have the right ability unlocked) take you to ANOTHER specific, fixed warp spot either in the same area or a different one.
It's COOL-looking, especially when you're warping between layers of a single area (it's 2.5D so you can move into the background and vice-versa) but it just makes going back for collectibles a bit more of a pain than it needs to be, ESPECIALLY with how huge the areas are.
It's not a problem if you like the gameplay and don't mind running back and forth, but it does make the game a bit longer than it really could've been if you go for 100%.



The graphics are [i]decent[/i] for what it is; it's not a very colorful game as the originals were, but the environments are varied enough and actually DO have different marked color schemes to make them easier to make out (the sewers having lots of greens, the temple browns, the factory blues, military areas being reddish, etc). They're old but they're more than serviceable for what they are.
Characters don't move their mouth when speaking though which makes cutscenes a bit funny to look at, but I can forgive that considering this game didn't really have that big of a budget to begin with.


The music's... [i]fine[/i], it serves its purpose during gameplay well, but there's not that many memorable memories here. I just finished [b]100%ing the game[/b] and I only remember about two or three melodies tops.


The story is... simple, honestly. The game jumps STRAIGHT into gameplay with not that much emphasis on cutscenes, and the story is simple enough that it doesn't need it. Stop the evil cultist dude that took over not-Russia. It's a retelling of the first game's plot which was an [i]arcade[/i] game, so there's your point of reference.
There's a lot of unlockable gallery extras that give you tidbits of information on each character and area though, which is actually pretty cool if you actually want to know more about these not-very-well-explained characters and locales.



Overall? Yeah, I like the game, minor gameplay design gripes aside. It's REALLY damn good for what it is, for the year it came out, and for the small budget it was given.


[b]That said, there is a rather IMPORTANT bug in this PC release that has not been addressed by the game's negligent parent Capcom.
If your CPU has more than 8 cores, the game will simply refuse to launch, crashing instantly upon trying to open it.
It can be fixed, but it requires a workaround found on the forums/guides, which could take upwards of 20-30 minutes and REALLY should not have been necessary to begin with.
Once it's fixed it runs really well, but be warned that depending on your rig you may need to go through the process to get it running.
[i]Capcom please. DON'T be like this to your creations, it hasn't even been 10 years since it came out for crying out loud..[/i][/b]

139803572.review:
Strider is a [i](both literally and metaphorically)[/i] fast paced scrolling Metroidvania. While a very short game, it's a wonderful experience to play for a day or two, and it doesn't overstay it's welcome.

Strider's Graphics are good. Not great, just good. There are sweeping vistas to see, combined with stylized characters and anime effects. It also plays a lot with vibrant colors, and things ARE color coded which adds to the style. It certainly can feel a bit jumbled, but it all comes together to make the game look quite nice.

Audio is a bit of both. Voice Acting is not good, it's just plain old bad. Everything else is passable, if not quite good. Satisfying hits, joyous level up sounds, and good mechanical sounds from threats.

The story is just OK. It's very minimalist, with very little being explained to you and with most exposition coming from either rare cutscenes or in characters speaking to you while you're moving in the world. You're Hiryu, on a mission to kill Grand Master Meio. That's about as deep as it gets, but that doesn't have to be a bad thing. 

The gameplay is the big draw here though, with it being a tight, well built Metroidvania. I mentioned earlier that it's short, and it is. I am not great at Platformers or Metroidvanias, but even I was able to beat the game on Normal in under 4 hours. Now, I'd say that this is a GOOD thing. Because, everytime you gain a new ability or attack, you have a short while to experiment with it before getting the next one, without a massive amount of time spent just fighting for the sake of fighting instead of actually progressing. Movement is incredibly slick, with controls mostly working to perfection. It does have that issue where when you're holding down to try and pass through a floor, sometimes you'll slide instead of go down, but that's about the worst that comes out of the control scheme. 

The map, while a bit big, never feels like you don't know where you're going. Secrets can still be explored for, but the game also gives you a directional arrow on your map menu in case you want to move on. You will want to explore too, as being able to spam your cool abilities and being able to tank a lot of hits is locked behind getting Energy and Health upgrades, which are found while exploring.

Bosses are fun too. Never overly challenging, but none after the mid point are a cakewalk, and none are a cakewalk period if you're playing on Hard.

It's just a tight, short and fun Metroidvania that is certainly worth a few bucks. As of writing this it's on sale for $4.5 USD, and that is a bargain.

Cool Kakashi looking guy chops and annihilates hordes of enemies in a urgent rush. But the game has an unimaginative Story yet its backed by an enjoyable combat and character movement experience. I only know this guy from Arcade games as a kid. I was hoping for it to be amazing, but it sadly isn't.

The biggest issue with the game is the lackadaisical story. There is no proper introduction to the world or the character Strider Hiryu, nor anything about the motivation of the character. The ending is even more underwhelming.

The collectables and the power upgrades feel very awkwardly placed. Distracting from the hurried experience of slicing through hordes of enemies. I hated how poor the travelling between maps/levels were set in place.  It was very tiring to go through the same route again and again just to see if you have missed a collectable or an upgrade for your weapon.
The combat is brilliant, i loved how varied yet simple the attacking options were. The character movements are also great, as everything feels fast paced and rushed. 

They could have made this soo much better, had the team had a credible script. The voice acting felt so generic, the main rarely spoke and when he did he sounded like a lost goof. Strider had potential to be a great game but was limited by too many of these short comings.
 
If you want to experience a different style of gameplay and enjoy rushed combat. You will enjoy this game. But if you like a well rounded experience with a good story/ motivation. You should give this game a pass.

137535036.review:
Strider's glow up is simply amazing, and the fact this game isn't praised nearly as much as it should is tragic. Strider is mostly know from Marvel Vs. Capcom 2 despite having 2 other games he starred in. Strider 2014 though easily sets up such a memorable version of himself that honestly whenever I think about the character, the fast paced, metroidvania version is all I think about.

The game is all about hitting hard and fast, like a ninja, and using the environment and enemies projectiles against them. A large portion of this games is simply rushing through enemy mobs as you reflect all the bullets they throw at you while performing cool tricks and triangle jump your way to the next location. With the way Strider 2014 uses movement also helps cement it as one of the cooler games to see when performed at higher play as there's just a cool amount of slips and slices that you can do while mowing down enemies. Bosses are even given great care to just how fun and challenging they can be, and while they can be brief, they are high action, and always a fun change of pace.
Aesthetically, Strider 2014 is a direct contrast of what you'd normally think of a ninja fighting an evil organization would look like. Everything about this game is super high tech, and all the environments and music help reinforce just how foreign Strider is to it, and how well he adapts to it throughout the game, often using various upgrades he finds throughout, both powering him up and helping him move even faster.

Mostly Strider 2014 is a hidden gem that Capcom doesn't advertise nearly as much as it should, and if you are interested in some high octane Metroidvania fun, Strider is easily a great pick.

135570659.review:
Strider is great, a 7/10. Here's the good news first:

1. Combat is fast paced and feels almost completely within your control. Movement feels fluid and fun.

2. The spammable basic slash attack very much makes you feel like an unstoppable super ninja from the very beginning. Charge strike also feels very satisfying to use.

3. Charge Mode feels awesome to use. You earn it through landing enough attacks while not getting hit too much. It's a super ability that rewards player skill, setting the tone for what will enable you victory in this game.

4. All aspects of combat are able to be mastered, meaning your fate is mostly controlled by your skill level.

The bad news:

1. Enemy variety gets boring to look at fairly quickly. 
You won't really be visually astonished by any of the enemies you encounter. There is basic foot soldier, soldier with shield, flying robot, big robot, and c r a b (they don't look like crabs).

2. Hiryu can take a shitton of damage in a very short amount of time.
He has no invincibility frames at any point. Add this to the fact that Hiryu can be hitstunned means that he can take a massive amount damage in less than a second and there isn't a real way to stop this other than to move fast enough out of the way in the right direction. Hiryu also can get hitstunned while struck in mid-air, and will begin falling once he's hit. Certain attacks also make him lose his grip while climbing. All these factors combined lead to many moments in the game that feel outright cheap and undeserved. These moments can be mitigated after getting Option A, however, which provides a momentary projectile shield.

3. Bosses are either too weak or too cheap.
Many bosses can be defeated simply by spamming the melee attack and moving around a moderate amount. This only gets easier later on once you realize you can combo the eagle and panther upgrades together into your flurry of regular attacks. Bosses can be stopped and stunned if you inflict enough damage on them. This leads to the interesting effect of not knowing a boss had a certain attack until you happen to stop beating on them. The final boss is disappointingly weak to fight against, especially in his biblical angel final form.

4. Hiryu's first jump has a strange quirk. 
When doing a single jump starting from forward moving momentum, he will jump forward normally, and you wouldn't suspect anything would be off about this jump until you try to turn backwards while in mid-air.  When switching to backwards movement in Hiryu's first jump, he will turn backwards instantly and retain the same speed as he was moving forward. This sounds minute in description, but it can throw off your rhythm in combat as he'll move in a direction at a speed you did not expect. It's a not intuitive and can be hard to get used to. It's further strange that his first jump has this property considering neither his second jump nor his plasma catapult jump have this quirk.

5. Hiryu's climbing also has some odd quirks. 
To start climbing on a surface you have to press the directional button matching the direction you have to grab it from (press up to grab ceiling, press left to grab wall on the left), but this is not always true. For example, if you are running in a straight direction to the left and reach a dropoff point, Hiryu will sometimes not drop off and start falling but instead will grab the wall that's perpendicular to the floor's dropoff. Hiryu can also freeze enemies, which effectively turns them into blocks you can use for climbing. Moving into a mid-air frozen enemy can cause you to grip onto them when you meant to attack them. This can happen a fair amount in late game, where there are many enemies in a small room that can be frozen.

6. Story is bad.
It's a cliche hero-comes-in-to-save-the-world-from-big-evil-Hitler-guy-and-hero-wins kind of story. A weak narrative can be mitigated by having the characters or character dynamics be compelling or interesting, but not even these are here. The lore isn't very interesting to read either.

7. Voice acting is bad and feels forced.
The dialogue for the English script is outright cringy once you hear the voice actors speak their lines. Hiryu has a bad Japanese accent, the Pooh sisters (yes, fuckin Pooh) sound really forced in their evil bitch monologues, the insane scientist goes laughably overboard in his "hehe I'm cwazy" speeches, General Mikiel and another side character have bad lazy Russian accents, the scientist Schlange (yes, fuckin Schlange) is the worst sounding of them all, and the final villain Grandmaster Meio is just... plain. You can tell these actors showed up for a paycheck and nothing else.

8. Exploration and unlockables are underwhelming.
The development team didn't really try much when it came to what is often the best part about games: exploration and being rewarded for said exploration. It can be fun to get new upgrades, but the same animation is used everytime you get one and it gets old. Upgrades and extras are placed in rather easily spotted and reachable areas. For extras, they simply recycled the concept art and character models that were created for the game, attached some lazily written lore to them and called it good enough. There are the Beacon Run and Survival challenge mode maps that can be unlocked too, but those don't provide much incentive in of themselves to play.

8. Achievements.
Achievements are a little odd. The achievement for beating General Mikiel tends to not unlock after beating him the first time on Hard mode. There is also an achievement for grabbing all large health canisters, but no achievement for finding all unlockable extras. No achievements exist for meeting any conditions in the Beacon Run and Survival mode challenges. On Xbox, the game can also bug out if you don't force quit it for a few hours and it'll somehow think you're not connected to Xbox Live, and therefore won't record any new achievements you should've gotten. Uncertain if this bug can happen beyond Xbox.

Fun Facts:

- The giant millipede bosses are actually several crabs attached together. The crabs did this willingly. 



The crabs willingly attached their mouths to each others' anuses.






- The Brainwalker units are called so because they are controlled by actual brains. Human brains. Civilian brains. 



They abducted civilians and put their brains into robots.







- The coolest sounds in the game (I personally believe) come from the mechanized dragon boss roars and the shield soldiers' voice line, "GO NO FURTHER!".

135534920.review:
At first I wanted to give this game a recommendation on the basis that it’s not broken. You can play it without hating it. But I ended up hating it. I’m not sure if games like these are supposed to have a good story but this one definitely doesn’t. It started off pretty standard but turned into nonsense and I started caring even less.

Combat was pretty cool at first but then I realized it was just mashing the attack button as fast as I could. Occasionally holding the attack button to hit enemies with shields. Over time it became mundane and boring. After the first mini boss the game decided that making a mini boss an normal enemy was okay. So I promptly restarted the game on easy difficulty. Thank god there is an easy mode.

I noticed that some checkpoints are not saved when you exit the game. Which is annoying. Jumping movement is a bit floaty and the character sometimes clings to a wall or a ledge when I just want to jump off of it. There are enemies that are annoying rather than difficult. 
Enemies respawn even if you didn’t leave the area.

Also I absolutely hated it when an enemy knocked me off of the top of a building and I had to climb back up. Or when I am trying to explore and go down the wall and accidentally touch a wire that shocks me and sends me tumbling down. One of my most hated things is that during a boss fight when they talk there will be a text block at the bottom that doesn’t let you see your character or the boss.

Visually it’s okay and the music sometimes is okay too. But definitely nothing special.
If you ask me why I played through the entirety of it is because I didn’t want to lower my average completion percentage.

It’s definitely a functioning game but ultimately it comes down to the question that Steam asked me: do you recommend this game. And the answer is NO.
Maybe if you’re a fan of the franchise.

134765866.review:
>>The Good<< 

-Decent Metroidvania-esqe level design with some fun gimmicks

-Very tight controls. You won't be slipping off things and you stop on a dime

-Excellent mobility. Fast movement speed, wall/ceiling clinging and climbing and later upgrades such as double jumping and multi directional dashing 

-Very fast 8 directional attacks

-Strong powers and upgrades with different properties for progress or combating enemies. Shout outs to the ability to deflect shots back at enemies with timing. Super satisfying

-Bosses are quite enjoyable and decently varied

-Good music, some nice remixes from older Strider games

-Strider Hiryu is cool as shit 


>>The Bad<< 

-Story is paper thin basic. You are super cool ninja man on a mission to assassinate super big evil Emperor Mayo. That is pretty much it. Less of an issue if you go into this with a "Who cares I'm just here to slash and style on people" mentality but still worth mentioning 

-Awkward cutscenes zooming in close to poorly textures models with zero facial animations despite them talking 

-No fast travel to any zone. There are fast travel points that lead to very specific points within a zone or to another specific zone but for the most part you will be traveling long distances if you are backtracking for missed upgrades due to not having an upgrade to access it early on and especially if you plan to get 100% completion. Massive slog and time waster 

-Some powers are a little too strong making some bosses go by like nothing 

-The game despite feeling great to slash through countless enemies very fast it is a little braindead and you will be mashing the attack button very very often

-Two of the four Cypher upgrades are meh and you'll most likely only ever use them when you absolutely have to to progress or to break an enemy's shield that requires it to break it

-The game has a very bad habit of crashing for many players (myself included) way too often, becoming borderline impossible to complete the game. I am not sure exactly how or why this happens but there is a Steam thread post by user "X6205" with a possible fix that worked for me. 
Link here: https://steamcommunity.com/app/235210/discussions/0/2575445991822522940/#c2974023280301011959 


>>Conclusion<< 

Overall Strider 2014 is a very solid B-tier small game for those who want to feel like an overpowered ninja on speed while moving and looking stupid cool. Its a game that very much values "Rule of Cool" over anything else, mostly being carried by it but still remaining mechanically very solid. Worth a shot if that's what your looking for and especially if you've played and enjoyed Strider 2 back in the day. Takes a lot from that game and the original arcade game from 1989.

134742499.review: Strangely underrated metroidvania: really fun core combat and platforming system, cool bossfights and very enjoyable visually. I always find it really strange nobody ever talks about this game or Strider in general when it's so much fun.

134710987.review:
Positives

The world is big but not overwhelmingly so, it also rewards exploring by hiding upgrades, collectables and different costumes off the beaten path for you to find.

The gameplay is just fun, Hiryu moves at a rather fast pace and just slicing through the enemies and moving through the world is satisfying and and very fun.

The bosses offer a great challenge without being unfair, I needed a few tries at the later bosses of the game but never felt like I got unfairly killed (I played on hard mode)

Three different difficulties, making the game accessible for beginners and challenging for veterans.


Negatives

I found the music unmemorable.

Hiryu controls very floaty, making precision platforming a problem... Though luckily the game rarely requires that kind of platforming but I found this still noticeable.

Barely any variety in enemies.

On occasion the game has segments that feature anti-gravity, causing Hiryu to be required to walk on walls and the ceiling... Luckily this is not something that happens often, but the controls during these parts are very awkward and for me at least were the only part of the game that genuinely frustrated me.


Quick summery

The game took me about 5 hours to beat on hard mode, this is without going for 100% completion though so for people that wanted to they certainly could get a few more hours of playtime out of this this.

It generally is simply a fun metroidvania but not exactly an outstanding one, I will give it a 7/10 and definitely recommend it for fans of the genre.

Strider es adictivo, siempre y cuando el juego no crashee, claro. No obstante, apetece jugarlo constantemente debido a la satisfacción de derrotar a tantos enemigos y de ir trepando y saltando por los tejados, pero no tiene nada más.

Un buen remake que te hace querer seguir jugando por lo divertido que es el gameplay, pero no aporta nada más.

125451379.review: While Strider has its share of problems, it is a pretty good metroidvania regardless of them. The controls are very fluid and the combat system with four varied types of 'plasma' is challenging but fair and skill-based. I found boss-fights to be particularly enjoyable due to their diversity and nicely balanced difficulty. There are probably more difficulty spikes in regular levels than in boss-fights. Those spikes, to me, are usually related to the fact that, when there are several enemies on the screen at once, it is easy to get stunlocked and lose majority of health bar within seconds. However, that is a design choice rather than a bug, so it might not necessarily be a flaw. Also, some of the environments could definitely do with a bit more variety because they are incredibly bland at times. It is the gameplay that counts mostly and all in all, the game is okay; it does not really shine in any aspect but it is definitely enjoyable. With a different rating system, it would probably be  a 7/10 or 6,5/10 for me.

125449919.review:
I may be a little biased since I played this during my early childhood, but I think its really good.
The gameplay mechanics feels extremely satisfying, the many different ways how you can kill the robot guards also add variety to the game. I think the story is alright for this game, I'd rate it solid 8/10 for quality.
Graphicswise, it is expected for a game that came out 2014 and playing this in 2022, it still looks fantastic I'd say. Not too bad, but not something that would look out of place in terms of modern games. It also runs very well given that I have 7 year old hardware and a constant 60fps is achievable. 
I will give a small little pick out, its very minor, that it couldn't run at 144fps. I think this would make the gameplay much more smoother and fluid, but I guess there are certain limitations that restrict the game from running past 60fps so I understand that. 
Overall I think this is a solid game 8/10, 9 years after I was introduced to this game, I still haven't lost interest in it (hopefully) and it is nice to relive parts of my childhood too

125426301.review:
XBox Live-core Metroidvania that holds your hand (via waypoints) with a few good ideas but some questionable design choices.

This is more of a 'Meh' review than a 'Not Recommended'. I chose No to attempt lowering this game's review score from the mid-80's down to the 70's where I think it belongs.

I've become a big fan of the arcade original since encountering it with a middling first impression on MAME 10 years ago. I'm not trying to knock new Strider for a shift in genre, I just think it's an aesthetic step down from the original. The Saturday morning cartoon still talking heads that pop up constantly and the low-res 2.5D character models just feel so inescapably mid-2010s.

Map design is uninspired though there are a few neat-looking areas. There's no real thrill of exploration—one of the strengths of the genre—present in Strider. You always know where you need to go. Secret items always reveal themselves on the map whenever you get within two rooms of them.

It's not particularly hard, either. You don't really have to mix up your attack strategies with most enemies or bosses. It's try not to get hit and mash sword.

I find this disappointing because I like the legacy of this character so much.

124785866.review:
Ok, so, I don't recommend the game for one reason and I'll start with why despite really liking this game:
Straight up, if you have 'too many CPU cores'? You cannot play this game. It will not even boot. So you have to either disable cores or use software to fool the game into thinking you only have 8 or less cores. Completely, bonkers and I've never heard of a problem like this with any other game. I have 12 cores so the game just does not boot. 

Why I do recommend the game:
The game itself is a lot of fun, it's metroid-lite with really fast paced action and cool power ups. Don't go into this game expecting story because while there is some, it's mostly window dressing between the platforming and action. You gain abilities and gear to progress through either enemies or obstacles like Metroid/Castlevania, the ability to reflect bullets with your sword, throwing kunai, a cool ability that launches yourself forward through enemies or special doors.

The game is really cool and I've heard almost no one talk about it. Either that's due to capcom not marketing it well enough or the issues relating to CPUs- because apparently some have issues with crashing. The only reason I've been able to play this game is on Steam Deck & even with putting the game into standby mode I've had little to no issue. Runs really well even with the power setting turned down.  

So if you like Metroidvania &  have 8 cores or less, or a Steam Deck or whatever, this game is for you. 
Yes, I've heard you can disable cores to play the game, but if you think having to go into your system settings and turn off CPU cores is a fix? That's on you. I don't turn off hardware so I can play a game.

124196061.review:
System and Setup:

Windows 10 64bit
Intel Core i9 10900K
NVIDIA GeForce RTX 2080 SUPER
27 inch 1440p 144hz monitor
2 TB SSD Hard Drive

The game won't launch if your PC's CPU has more cores than the game can handle. I wrote a guide on how to fix that here:

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2874936610

Opinion:

While I wouldn't consider Strider a game that should be at the top of the list of the best metroidvanias, it is absolutely a good game that any fan of the genre or the character should enjoy playing. Whereas other games focus either on ranged combat or a slower, more deliberate melee, Strider is about becoming an unstoppable force that obliterates anything unfortunate enough to stand in your way, similarly to how the old arcade games played.

The only notable downside I can see is that, well, the graphics took a little while to acclimate to. Being a primarily 7th gen game wasn't the problem, it's that the game deliberately imposes a faux-scanline effect on the screen that just doesn't look that great. It nearly put me off of replaying the game, but I overcame it as the familiar traits of the genre hooked me. Fun boss battles, cool power-ups and the compulsion to search every last inch of the map to get every single item!

Having played this game already on the PS4, I was worried that revisiting this one in 2022 would be a disappointment. I was wrong to be pessimistic and I'm glad I double-dipped on this one.

Recommended.

120203637.review:
Playing this game is a little strange as it is a great game and I find a few of the Boss Fights really creative and fun, but sometimes the game throw you this unexpected difficulty curve that just flat out kills you with stun lock nonsense from a few of the enemies (those damn lazer rifle guys and freeze shotgun guys). I mean at times when it gets you off guard it is very frustrating, but other times when you're in your groove it's really fun. So I guess it depends on where your state of mind is. This is a minor issue I have with the game though, overall, I love this game and knowing that this game came out quite some time ago, it is a very well designed game for it's time. 

One actual critic I do have is the back tracking design of the game, it's not really a "Metroidvania-friendly" with access points to travel in between maps, you do have those but you still need to traverse a few places before you get to your desired map for item hunting. It's far in between is what i am saying, and maps are more of a cut pieces that are joined together to make "world map", then these cut pieces are also in sections, so you can imagine doing backtracking can be a little tedious. But, it is NOT game breaking though, as the level designs are awesome. Like it really came from a time of those 8-16bit era where the emphasis on level design is part of the game Dev's philosophy which is also tied to enemy design and behavior. Good stuff! 

other than my minor issues that I have with this game, I do recommend this game. It is an Awesome side-scrolling Strider Game!

120136934.review:
While playing Strider I quite honestly thought it was a 2008-era Xbox Live Arcade title akin to Bionic Commando Rearmed or similar and so I should feel less aggrieved by its shortcomings. Finding out it actually came out after the release of the PS4 and Xbox One actually makes it much worse than I thought.

Strider is a remake/reboot of a very old game from the Nintendo/Genesis era, so it can be understood for being so simplistic, but it doesn't make it any better. Having had years of development to make this game into something more substantial and subsequently failing to do so doesn't feel great. There is extremely little to the game, mostly running around the screen and mashing the attack button. There are additional powers and variations on it but throughout the game, there is extremely little use for them other than the occasional enemy requiring a slight change in tactics. For the vast majority, there is next to nothing beyond this leaving the game extremely simple and dull. The boss fights are similar, not requiring much more than being able to jump up to where they've decided to draw the fight out at and mashing the attack button further.

There are several collectibles but they aren't gratifying to collect and give little in return. Map exploration is simplistic and lacks any sort of Metroidvania retreading or discovery. This game is about as empty as it gets and the only saving grace is that it can be grabbed for cheap.

If you're of the opinion that gaming peaked in the 8-bit or 16-bit era and desperately want a game that feels like a modern graphical update of that time period this game is for you. If you're looking for anything of substance or entertainment Bionic Command Rearmed is an infinitely better proposition along with many other retro-inspired modern indie games.

119403815.review:
[h3]Review after at least 30 minutes:[/h3]
Strider (6 hours at time of writing.)
[b][u]Did I enjoy it?[/u][/b] - Oh heck, yeh.
[b][u]Will I come back to it?[/u][/b] - Mos' Definitely. I'd like to finish this one at least once.
[b][u]Was it worth my time?[/u][/b] - Yeah, I have really enjoyed my time with it so far.
[b][u]Would I recommend it?[/u][/b] - Yes! If you enjoy action focused metroidvanias at all, this is well worth your time.

[b][u]First Impressions:[/u][/b]
I was immediately charmed by this games and found it difficult to stop during my first session. I'm hoping it can keep me hooked until the end. This feels like a game I'm going to want to come back to enjoy all the way through again! 
It's harder for me to articulate what is working for me in a game, so don't be put off by the short Pros section. I think this is a sign that I'm too sucked in playing the game to think about why I'm having fun.

Pros:
[list]
[*]Great combat
[*]Compelling pace and progression
[*]Exploring the map is rewarding with power-ups and extras in plentiful supply
[*]Just F---ing fun!
[/list]

Cons:[list]
[*]The player character's movement can feel a bit sticky and awkward at times, especially when maneuvering tight quarters. I can get stuck to walls and ceilings easily which can get in the way when fighting. Sometimes certain moves require a bit more precision than I like, such as detaching when climbing. 
[*]Attack direction is effected by the surface that you're standing on and can make hitting certain targets difficult and frustrating, but this a rare occurrence.
[*]The controls feel a bit awkward in situations where I'm charging and want to attack with one of my 'Options'. It's frustrating wanting to save a charge while at the same time attacking with an option, but I acknowledge it's a nit-pick.
[*]Unskippable cut-scenes are a more obnoxious problem, especially when difficult bosses have opening speeches. It doesn't seem like much but 5 to 15 seconds really starts to wear on me after the first time. Any action game that's going to have cut-scenes ought have an option to skip them (at least after the first time!). I'd like to see more games with an auto-skip option in the menus, extra brownie points for that!
[*]Enemies tend toward feeling tanky with too much health. That's a tricky balance, but I think it's a valid concern considering longer health bars require more mashing of the attack button which can really start to hurt after a long session. The most difficult boss I've fought so far became a frustrating not just because of the (quite enjoyable) challenge, but also because my hands were starting to hurt due to the repetitive movements. Multiplied by the number of deaths, this became a pretty unpleasant experience. 
[list][*]I think an accessibility option for auto rapid-fire, or a separate control for charged attacks, could be helpful solutions in other games. [/list]
[/list]

[i]I'm trying to review more games by using this format. If you have kind feedback, please leave a comment.[/i]

119088901.review:
Decent enough metroidvania, but gets repetitive over time and navigating the map for completion get's really tiresome over time. Not a bad game, but not one I would recomend either.
Pros:
Tight controls, serviceable story, interesting take on the Strider franchise.
Cons:
Repetitive enemies, bosses, and the map design starts showing it's flaws near the end.

The game allows you to change the properties of Strider's attacks by changing the color of his plasma scarf, which is an interesting ability. The problem however, is that it affects all of your abilities at once, so not only you can't mix and match without having to quick swap them during combat, but all of your abilities share similar attributes, making them less unique. Additionally, there's no change to your special attacks, which could've added some much needed variety.
This plasma system translates into enemies being largelly the same across the whole game, except some more obnoxious ones being color coded.
On the map, while it mostly consists of industrial style enviroments, it's decently varied, but navigation gets obnoxious in late game, as you move across areas with more frequency, they start blending together.
Certain areas can only be reached through specific routes and a specific example of bad design is the temple, which has a ring that you can fall into accidentally into, with a launcher that sends you into the prison, and the hatch that closes right behind you, so there's no way back, and the way out of the prison has a gauntlet that forces you to go through several rooms locked until you defeat the enemies inside.
Additionally, in order to complete the game 100%, you need find several collectibles, which are all very interesting, except one, the health canister. This canister just recovers your health, so if you don't need it, naturally you tend to ignore it over time. However, despite not adding anything to your overall character progression, these count for game completion, so you end up being forced to backtrack to destroy items you already found before but didn't know were important, because, well, they really weren't.

Overall, if you don't mind about completing the game 100%, and would like some Strider action, this game is non-offensive, but as a metroidvania, it lacks in several aspects.

118881216.review:
[b]Score: 3/10[/b]

The fundamentals in Strider are comfortable, but the execution of every single facet of the game varies from mediocre to abhorrent. I blew through the game at an intense pace to keep myself interested, and yet could not escape the boredom of a dull, terribly-voice-acted story and one-dimensional combat. The best part of the game is far and away the silly pleasures of beating the pits out of every single thing that shows up in front of you, but every moment where you start to enjoy that is interrupted by an enemy specifically designed to roadbump your fun and keep the pacing through each level tedious and formulaic. Why in the world is the second most common enemy in a game about spamming the attack button till your finger hurts a shield-user that SPECIFICALLY stops you from spamming? It is taking the fun part of the game, that is well and wholly acknowledged by health dropping from each enemy, and asking you to stop doing it every 15 paces. Asinine. Without any form of a progression system, you eventually realize that most enemies are optional, and the anti-fun shield guys no longer become an issue since you're hopping and zipping over their heads to the next boss. Which... range from okay to awful gameplay-wise, and consistently terrible in voice-acting (which is BAD bad, not fun bad). Music was almost never noticeable, though it doesn't really become a nuisance at any point. Boss themes are... I can't remember enough about them to say anything, which is a negative in my book. Ultimately, here's what you get - 10 seconds of slashy fun, then you have to charge up a swipe for a shield guy but you get bumped midway through the charge and have to restart it. Then you get bumped again, which sends you into a wall trap that pinballs you to the other side of the room. The nearest enemy then freezes you and you jump to avoid him, snapping to the ceiling, which you won't realize for a few seconds because six bombs are going off inside your character model. You realize this, drop down, and have another 10 seconds of fun. There are far better in this genre, buy something else.

Oh, also, the keybinds are unchangeable. Probably play this with a controller.

118227937.review:
I've played this once before back at release and I'm happy to say it still rocks. Note that while my performance on my 1070 was buttery smooth, there are known issues with certain cpus and graphics cards so make sure to test upon purchase and see if you need to refund. 

Strider is a fantastic 2d action exploration game that gets most everything right, and what it gets wrong is easily dismissable. You play as a cyborg ninja taking on a bunch of techno russians and their cyborg mercernaries hired to take you out. Its flashy, chaotic, and smoothly balanced, with plenty of fanservice to the original Strider games of yesteryear but taking an honest approach to the established Vania format. Functionally, you slice, you dice, and you dash, and over the course of the game you find more ways to do all of the above in even more engaging ways. Like Metroid: Dread years later, it maximally uses the 2.5d space to full effect, with enemies coming in and out the arena, camera changes for dynamic effect, and constantly utilized sense of depth to each inch of the map. While some areas are hit or miss as far as visual engagement, there is a ton of variety in set pieces and scenarios you're thrust into, with some really beautiful midgame backdrops calling back to the classics being among my favorite. It is at its worst serviceable and clean, making it easy to navigate without getting lost, and the dynamic layered map certainly helps.

Gameplay is generally sublime--you can swing your sword as fast as you can hit the button, and all the various mechanical variety introduced later on blends pretty seemlessly into the general flow of the game. My biggest issues stem from the generally boring enemy types you face; robot soldier with gun, with rocket launcher, or with SHIELD and gun make up the majority of encounters, with the occasional miniboss sprinkled throughout. By the end of the game you will have seen every feasible variation on robot soldier, and you will come to hate the shield guys, who start requiring certain elements to break. Unlike many games with shield dudes, you cannot use your fantastic ninja skills to get behind them and slash them to death--for some reason they have more agility than you, the cyborg ninja, and will snap around to block any and all attacks unless its a charged attack or the matching element. While "challenging" near the end game, these guys kill the flow in how limited your options are, and stand as the only enemy that works like this. 

Blessedly, bosses welcome whatever strategy you feel like. There are the obvious advantages on certain ones, but you're never punished for variety, and most are memorable in their spectacle and design. WIthout spoiling, while the final boss is as cheesy as the rest of the game, beating it rewards you with probably the best credits background victory screen I've ever seen, and is so incredibly badass that it makes the entire game worth it just to see. While I played the game on normal, I found myself dying to more platforming than the bosses, and would recommend anyone wanting a challenge to play on hard. Unlike previous games, boss encounters once gleaned are often the easier experiences, made difficult only by some of the more obnoxious moves and massive health pools. The big bad in particular has an orb attack that deals massive damage and follows you around the map--if there was a way to destroy it I never could figure it out. ultimately you just have to gauge what your best DPS tactics are. I liked the eagle the most for this, but even then by the end I hated how even the common grunts could take 6 or so slashes to the face before dying and late game encounters end up just being damage trading.

The biggest sins this game commits are in its weak story--which isn't so bad in itself--and the fact that it insists to take up a full 6th of the screen when its being exposited to you. For some reason, even though all the dialogue is voiced, the game has these massive text boxes pop up and caption everything the villain of the moment is saying. There is no way to disable these from what I can tell or shrink this box, which is a problem--they are not opaque, and because Strider tends to orient camerawise lower on the screen, these incessent, often repeating quips COVER where you and enemies can be, as well as obscure pitfalls and dangers. It is particularly bad in the early game, and overall I would say that the first 20% of this game is the weakest it gets, which isn't great. While the initial introductions to bosses and such is welcome at first, this game does not know when to shut up--which means you're going to have to do guess work as to where youre going a lot. This isn't helped by the fact that you will come to realise you've effectively seen the entire bestiary in the first 5 minutes--turrets, soldiers, and big mech soldiers. Thankfully the flow of the game encourages you to ignore most mobs, but later on many get tracking shots and elemental attacks that can ruin you if you get clipped, and the general flow becomes frustrating. I've already spoken of the shield guys, but thats that. It's a shame, because the actual combat options available to you are varied and unique and calls for an equally varied enemy set to compliment, but because grunts at most take a quick change in element to slice down in a hit or two, it's barely utilized outside of bosses.

The other mixed bag is platforming. First off, like any good metroidvania, there is sequence breaking, and its not that difficult to do. The game is definitely not coded for it but it thankfully has contingencies in case it happens, so feel free to break the waypoint system and watch bosses you've already defeated say theyre about to arrive. That is fun! What isn't fun is the weird, wonky hit boxes, the HORRENDOUS knockback enemies and environment have, and the inconsistent wallgrabbing mechanic that is essential to it all. Its not really noticable early game, but by the end of the game you're going to be flipping coins wondering if you'll even grab the ledge. Luckily the game is incredibly forgiving and (usually) doesn't set you back too far if you screw up, and while I appreciate that, its a bandaid to a bigger wound. When it works its as good as any speedy game in the genre, but you certainly feel it when things go awry. Another more minor issue I have is that the game never gives you any high speed moves, and while you move fast enough from the start, I was practically begging for a faster sprint option with how tediously long and winding some areas could get. 

The final annoyance I have is the weird completionist requirements needed to finish the maps. For anyone like me who want to get everything yourself, you're out of luck; while upgrades are visible on the map, there are also hidden collectible intel and concept art filling the hidden corners of the world that are not--meaning you're going to need a guide to 100% everything, and they all count towards your final score. Also, so do the large health refills for some bizarre reason.

All being said, Strider is a fantastic reboot by a now notorious studio (you would know them as the Killer Instinct reboot folks, or more recently the Amazon New World MMO), and its genuinely incredible this was the only game of its kind they made. The experience is superb and is one of the better metroidvanias out there, especially for the time. If MercurySteam could go from that awful 3ds castlevania game to the pinnacle of the Metroid series in Dread, it makes me wonder what this studio could've made if it hadn't sold its soul. Probably wishful thinking knowing how cutthroat the industry is, but I would have loved to have seen a sequel with this from what they learned. As it stands however, this is a mindblowingly good game and shouldn't be missed by newcomers and verterans alike. It goes on sale often and is worth every penny, caveats and all. Be the robot killing cyborg ninja you've always wanted to be.

This game has aged fairly well. I recommend this game more to fans of action platformers than to metroidvania fans though.  The map design makes trying to collect 100% of the items very tedious and I normally don't mind backtracking in games.

However, if you approach it more like an action platformer it holds up pretty well.  Running through the game linearly with some exploration to grab some powerups is the way to go.  Also without some health and energy upgrades the end of the game would be very, very difficult.  The controls feel good (for the most part, gets a little weird  when they play with gravity), enemy and boss design is functional if not the most creative stuff in the world.  Overall the moment to moment gameplay feels good.

It does lean towards the more frustrating end of challenge at points as you can be stunlocked by certain groups of enemies because Strider takes just long enough to recover to take another hit that knocks you over.    Overall though that issue didn't bother me that often, but it did happen a few times.

For me the only truly horrible thing is the voice acting and cutscenes. Especially the robotics scientist in the research area.  Thankfully you can skip most of it, except the scientist guy who is genuinely ear grating to listen to.

As it is, this weird little forgotten Capcom game is pretty fun and worth owning imo.

109161936.review:
This game is worth a look for people who like tight platforming and fast-paced gameplay.

I like what they tried to do with the source material here, futurizing Strider's aesthetic and building a larger world to explore in Kazakh City. I see some compare this game to a metroidvania, but I don't know if this game is for that crowd- Exploring yields collectibles, but the game always shows you where you need to go next, so the game isn't quite built for problem solving in that way. As a Strider game, it's fantastic, with plenty of fun movement and intense combat. There's plenty of fun boss fights and the game barely breaks pace for anything. It can take a bit to get used to due to there being no tutorial, and certain parts of the game like anti-gravity segments or tight corridors can be frustrating to move through. There's also no i-frames when taking damage, so being in the wrong corner could just kill you-Just accept the rough edges and enjoy the ride.

Aside from the main game, there's a couple challenges and replay incentives, but nothing too crazy. It's at least worth a try for someone up for a challenge.

106669369.review:
Fantastic reboot of the series. Apart from some bothersome slowdowns (bothersome because my system greatly exceeds the recommended system requirements) and a bit of repetition, this is a quality game through and through. 

Instead of making the game in 3D and getting a mixed response from older fans, they kept the side-scrolling gameplay and made it in a metroidvania style. This is great because it is a „best of both worlds” kind of approach. The 2,5D graphics look great and the gameplay will be imediately familiar for fans of the older games. 

Some might say that the game is a little too short at just 7 hours on the easiest difficulty, but it is worth mentioning that unlike other games, there are very few cutscenes and all are very short (under a minute). Of the 7,3h of play at the time of this review, more than 7h was practically gameplay, not me watching a cutscene. So when you think about it, this game actually has quite a good length. Plus it is considerably longer than the other games in the series, with bigger areas to explore. 

I consider this the best game in the series. While I did not play Strider II (Amiga), i did play Strider (Genesis), Strider 2 (PS1) and a little of Strider (NES). Apart from the fact that it's not as innovative in terms of gameplay and graphics as the first Strider, it has the better gameplay of the series, that will probably age better as well.

Another great game from Capcom. Highly recommended!

106539128.review:
Strider (2014) is pretty great.  It's a 2D metroidvania, with a focus on action and combat.  As a kid, I played both the NES Strider and the Genesis Strider.  They were two very different games.  The NES strider was a straight metroidvania with small sprites.  A very good game.  The Genesis version was a straight action platformer with huge sprites, it had amazing visuals for its time.  The 2014 version of Strider feels like it combines all of the good things from those two old games.  

Strider is fast.  You move fast, you strike fast.  You run through the areas, slashing anything that gets in your way.  You have a great climbing hook that lets you latch onto any wall or ceiling.  Even when grappling around, you are still pretty fast, everything always feels great.  The action eventually moves past brainless slashing, as you get a charge attack, and different versions of your sword to use on different types of enemies, but it never becomes challenging enough to become frustrating.

Exploring in Strider is great.  There are secrets everywhere and using the aforementioned climbing hook is a joy.  As you get further in the game, you will acquire new skills that allow you to explore more, and backtrack and get pickups that you weren't able to earlier, like most other games in the genre.  The map is fine, and gives you the info you need.

Strider looks great!  While it takes place on a 2D plane, there is enough going on in the background, both nearby and far into the city that the world feels alive.   The animation and action is very smooth and feels like it should.  During some of the cutscenes game will zoom in on characters a little closer than it should, and you can see that some of the textures aren't quite up to snuff.  

I seem to have a soft spot for metroidvanias, and I have one for Strider for sure.  Not only did I play the two games I mentioned earlier, when I was young, but as a big fan of Capcoms fighting games, I have a lot of experience with the character.  That all being said, I very much enjoyed my time with Strider.  Two big thumbs up.  

8/10

99431412.review:
TL:DR, this is one of the most satisfying Metroidvanias I have ever played. Controls were tight, tons of upgrades and collectibles to find, beautiful graphics and music, it was tons of fun. But let's back it up a bit.

Just like the classics, Strider Hiryu is an assassin whose mission is to stop Grandmaster Meio from world domination. He'll have to brave through the city, military bases, underground labs, and more to stop his evil plans. Many enemies and obstacles will try to stop him. Can you help him save the day?

Strider plays like a platformer and Metroidvania meaning that you will be exploring maps and gaining new abilities, weaponry, and skills to gain access to new areas. The story is pretty simple like the classics so there's no deep plot, but the action keeps you hooked in. You start off with just your blade, but as the game progresses you can equip it with different elements and gain more gear. 

The frame rate is pretty smooth as well as the controls. Exploring areas was a lot of fun and if you are good, you can find tons of collectibles that range from concept art, to new costumes you can equip on Strider. Boss fights were very enjoyable. Most times if I found myself stuck on one, I learned what pattern I wasn't following correctly and was able to pass them. I was never stuck in an area or boss for a long amount of time and I always found that satisfying.

The game is a moderate length as I finished it in about 10 hours, but you can beat it faster if you don't look for collectibles (I got about 70 percent or so when I finished the game). I will say that my ONE gripe with this game is the lack of fast travel. You will unlock these short travel abilities that work between certain zones. However, when you reach the point of no return, there is no way to just hit a map and fast travel to a past area to look for collectibles you are missing. Some of the maps are HUGE so to have to walk through them is a hassle. Other than that, I had a great time with the game.

Final verdict? If you like Metroidvanias then you NEED this in your library. The action and gameplay were so great, I had fun looking for secrets, and the platforming puzzles offered a fair amount of challenge especially towards the end. Tons of collectibles to find will give you hours of gameplay to enjoy so you can't go wrong with this game. So gear up, grab your blade, and go save the world! Thanks for reading!

[h1]HC Reviews (Assassin Dark): [/h1]

Me decidí probar este título sin saber casi nada de el, solo sabía que era un reboot de un clásico de Capcom de 1989.

Strider es un plataformas de acción Hack and Slash, es un videojuego muy frenético con mecánicas bien desarrolladas, las mejoras de personaje, tipos de armas, estilos de combate, etc, todo eso hace que tengas muchas variantes a la hora de poner a prueba tus habilidades, 

Los escenarios están bien hechos, la música acompaña muy bien cada nivel, cumplen en meterte en la atmósfera de la historia, la cual es simple pero funciona bien.

Me encantó que a pesar de que es un videojuego lineal, es necesario explorar el mapa para conseguir mejoras de salud y energía para poder superar niveles con enemigos más poderosos, y poder acceder a zonas que antes no podíamos, la dificultad normal te tomará un par de intentos poder superar algunos bosses, pero nada complicado, en cambio, la hardcore, si será un verdadero reto para el jugador. 

Un gran videojuego, lleno de acción y mecánicas asombrosas que funcionan muy bien en toda la aventura.

96711470.review:
After some thought, I concluded that this game is worth to recommend. It has a lot of problems, like the terrible primary school level writing in the dialogues (you can't skip them), it starts slow, the first areas are boring and they are hard to tell apart from one another. As a metroidvania is very lacking since the exploration doesn't matter that much and the enemy design (both on artstyle and gameplay desing) are kinda generic and uninteresting.

However, if you manage to pass through the first areas and get some power-ups, the combat gets way better, you encounter better designed enemies and the exploration is actually enjoyable. The boss fights are nothing out of the ordinary, but they are well designed and fun to fight. 

Where this game really shines is when you got some power-ups that allows you to slash your way through the rooms like a ninja, and things can become really chaotic since you need to divide your attention on the large amount of enemies and switching between you power-ups to kill enemies with specific mechanics.

Overall this is a fun game, if you don't expect too much from it. If I have to give it a "journalist" score, it would be a solid 7/10 game.

Strider (2014) is a great game by itself and a phenomenal reboot to the series that began in 1989. The gameplay is probably this game strongest point as your character from very start feels nimble and acrobatic, with a satisfying combat that makes you feel like you're controlling an actual ninja...and all of this can be enhance by you exploring the map for upgrades. And yes, it's a metroidvania game.

Though this game is without it's flaw, the story is pretty barebone by itself and feels like it's from a Saturday morning cartoon with the characters going pretty hammy on their dialouges...except for the player character, Strider Hiryu which stay pretty stoic and silent through out the game and only speak when necessary but none of the character you'll meet will have any character development through out your roughly 6-8 hours journey

The OST for this game is pretty mid in my opinon as most of the tracks serves as a amibent for the levels and the sound of your unadulterated carnage will most likely overlap all the music in the game. I remember like 3 tracks which go pretty ham that are: Raid (Opening Stage), Kazahk Theme and The Armed Fortress

I haven't encountered too many bugs myself but I have heard some people on Steam forum that the game would crash if you have certain GPUs and the game key binds cannot be change in-game and you have to change it from a .ini file which should not be a thing even for a 2014 title. But that's about it

Overall, the game is great if you like metroidvania style game like Ori, Hollow Knight...OR if you just happen to know the character from a certain fighting game (Marvel vs. Capcom) and don't know where to start. This is a solid title to try out. I bought this game during the Summer Sale and can't play anything else during the weekend, it's so good 

8/10

92164876.review:
The runtime is only about 4-6 hours long, but you’ll be in for a good time with fluid controls, a fairly massive world to explore, lots of secrets to find, interesting abilities, and some pretty cool bosses. Any longer than that, though, and I think the game’s weak points of having samey-looking enviroments, poor enemy variety, and button-mashey combat would’ve made Strider overstay its welcome.

The story and characters aren’t much to write home about. It gets the job done, and features good voice acting, a badass protagonist, and it may occasionally make you want to punch a cocky villain in the face as they mercilessly tease you while you’re busy wrecking their shiz. Overall, the story is there, but the game doesn’t bog itself down with it, which I think is a good thing.

The environments are mostly of the ‘rundown city’, ‘industrial area’ and ‘sewer’ variety, with a good heaping of futuristic neon-lighting thrown in. They all kinda blend into each other and have very few landmarks, resulting in areas that rarely feel memorable or unique. And you won’t get much satisfaction from wandering into a boss’s lair and tearing him a new one, because it’ll all just feel like it’s taking place in room #3217 in Generic Industrial Building #87.

Even with he lack of environmental variety, the environments themselves are very finely detailed, with a lot to gawk at in the background. And it helps that the game’s graphics are more than serviceable enough, and  is even detailed enough to have objects reflect off of surfaces or buildings, which is a cool touch.

Thinking back on the sound effects, I also cannot say a whole lot aside from saying they were well done. Same with the music, which was sometimes catchy (to the point where I found myself humming one song even when I wasn’t playing the game). No complaints.

Regarding difficulty, this is a game you also want to play on Hard, as Hard is already rather forgiving, and Normal mode pretty much entirely lacks any challenge (especially considering how liberally checkpoints are sprinkled everywhere). Towards the mid-to-late game you may also find yourself just jumping over hoards of enemies and skipping combat entirely. However, there are a handful of encounters, mostly later in the game, that require a decent amount of skill, and bosses that will stomp you if you’re not paying attention or playing sloppily. At least for me, beating some of these encounters and bosses were genuinely challenging, and were quite satisfying to complete.

Overall, Strider is your standard Metroidvania fare. It’s not a masterpiece by any means, but it’s very polished, controls fluidly, and is fun enough for its duration. So I heartily recommend it.

92020919.review: I've played both of the original Strider Games and I can say this one deserves its place in the franchise. While I missed the mix of 2D sprites and 3D environments in Strider 2, Strider 3 brings a lot more to the table gameplay-wise. The biggest difference is that instead of an arcade style game broken into action stages, you're getting more of a "Metroidvania" experience in a large, interconnected world. Beyond that, you'll be climbing walls, hacking, slashing, and doing cartwheels in the air like the original games, but with a focus on exploration unlike the previous entries. It doesn't have as much charm as Strider 2, but you're getting a lot more content. Story is self-contained, so if you've never played the first 2, you can still follow along with what's going on. I recommend it for anyone, really.
