45451207.review:
I had a lot of fun with Strider. 

At first I was not impressed. The platforming controls felt imprecise and beating the early batch of enemies involved pure button mashing. The art style was unique but not mindblowing, and the music was par for the course for this sort of game. Meh.

BUT, I gave it it chance, and I'm glad I did, because as progress was made: the environments became more expansive, inviting exploration; a host of powers and upgrades become available, making combat more varied; and the enemies and platforming amped up in difficulty, which made the whole thing far more interesting. In short, I had to scratch beneath the surface to get to the good stuff. 

Good stuff it is, but not mindblowingly good. It does what it sets out to do nonetheless; it's  a great platformer that's pretty addictive, challenging in places, but always forgiving in the number of tries you can have. Also, the japanese anime and arcade sensibilities are well executed too if you like that sort of thing.  

Give it a whirl. I never played the original Strider so can't compare, but this game stands strong in it's own right.

45255946.review: Those who remember the original Strider will recall a fast-paced action arcade game- Strider 2014, however, is not an arcade-style game at all. Rather, it takes the foundational combat of Strider- running swiftly, making acrobatic jumps, and slashing enemies with your sword id rapid succession- and rebuilds that into the concept of a Metroidvania. You'll be exploring Kazakh City, acquiring new abilities, collection health and energy upgrades, and everything else you'd expect from the genre. Strider 2014 doesn't really do anything new- but then again, it doesn't need to. It's a fine game that has what you'd expect from a Metroidvania- nothing more, nothing less. Lots of hidden upgrades to collect, great boss fights, and all with  fair bit of style to it. I give this game a solid 8/10.

44730383.review:
Strider is a great reminded as to why Metroidvania style games will never go out of style.  The fact is it is extremely rewarding not only to continuously unlock new abilities but to be able to utilize those abilities to explore previously inaccessible areas.  What makes Strider stand out from many of the other games in the genre is how fast-paced and fluid your movements are.  Where many of the protagonists in these games use guns Hiryu relies on his sword to cut down his enemies; this forces the player to get up close therefore putting themselves in danger.  Although, there are a couple of quirks to address there is a lot of promising features in this title as well.

There is not much of a story in Strider, therefore your main goal is to use both you acrobatic and combat skills to get from point A to point B.  You merely start with the ability to jump up into air and swing your sword like a mad man.  You can also hold the attack button to charge a more powerful blow.  As you progress you'll unlock kunai to throw, giving you a much appreciated range attack.  You'll continue unlocking skills to improve your maneuverability such as slides and dashes.  Also you'll get different upgrades for your sword allowing it to utilize elemental effects such as fire and freezing.  Finally, you have robots called options which let you use a powerful ability at the cost of a meter which will slowly keep recharging.

Although, the platforming and exploration make up most of the experience the game does try to keep things interesting.  For one thing there are sections that offer increasing difficult combat scenarios with no breaks in-between.  The boss fights are the real highlight of Strider.  Each boss offers clever patterns you must learn and when you chip away a set amount of their health they will start to mix things up.  This really keeps you on your toes because as soon as you feel comfortable with one pattern you'll get a new one you'll have to learn quickly.  The Pooh sisters were a very interesting example since as you fight each new sister she will bring in the other sisters you previously defeated for back-up.  This results in forcing you to dodge and fight multiple bosses at the same time.

Strider features a surprising large world to progress through.  The world map is broken down into a handful of sections.  In each section your mini-map will fill in as you explore.  You'll also find a handful of rooms that will let you restore you're health as well as save your progress.  As you unlock new powers you'll be able to bring your map back up to see which doors you've passed can now be accessed.  You'll always have an objective marker to help keep you oriented at least till the endgame when you start backtracking for upgrades and secrets.  There are health, energy, and ability enchaining techniques to be found all over the world.  Secrets include concept art, story details, and challenge courses.

Without a doubt Strider is an enjoyable, fast-paced, metroidvania.  The combat and movement is frantic but as you progress you will start to master it.  Exploration is a huge part of these kinds of games and I wish they would have made it a little more accessible.  There really isn't any nice system to warp from one zone to another which would have been very useful when tracking down upgrades near the end game.  Although you can see the percentage of collectibles you have found in each zone but for some reason you aren't actually able to access each zone's mini-map unless you are in it.  These roadblocks seem completely unnecessary and they are pretty much the only thing holding this game back from being another classic.  If the small details don't bother you I'm sure you'll have fun with this modern side-scroller.

44288013.review:
A metroidvania that focuses on speed, but sadly doesn't have quite the mobility needed to get there. The combat is either effortless (most enemies you just mash the attack button), or slow (bosses and certain harder enemies require mostly jumping around while whittling their health bar down). While there are a couple of fast travel options, they sadly don't connect easily to many areas leading to somewhat painful backtracking if you want to get everything.

It is still a great deal of fun (games that are good, but have glaring flaws tend to get more complaints from me), so I would recommend playing it.

44151557.review:
Double Helix Games and Capcom took a stab at recreating a reimagined 1989 Strider videogame. What you have here is a Strider game that has not evolved. It is basically old school Strider with pretty graphics.

I know my gameplay stats is mighty low, but I just could not push myself to continue playing. The combat is overly simplistic. Enemies, predictable. 

The level designs are pretty well done for a 2.5D title. The verticality lends itself to the gameplay style, allowing Strider to make quick jumps and strikes to take down enemies. Controlling the character is a breeze. Controls are very responsive, making your character feel agile. The issue here is, the levels are too small, making you feel like a hamster in a box.

There is no ultra-wide 21:9 support. This is kind of a no-brainer considering many games, including Indie titles support 21:9 out of the box. While developers like to make it out to be that 21:9 takes too much time and money, I don't believe it one bit when small Indie studios support it right out of the box without question. But then again, this is Capcom we're speaking of.

I highly doubt I will revisit this game, as the core gameplay does not interest me one bit. It's too shallow to invest any worthwhile gameplay hours into it.

44127090.review:
Not much of a metroidvania here, since the game is pretty linear. Going back with your new items usually gets you some lesser power ups or collectables.

Game has a severe lack of personality. The hero is just a killing machine, trained to kill a dictator. The enemy bosses have no background, they are just ordered to kill you and thats it. No drama.

Difficulty is irregular. Levels are just filled with enemies that shoot at you and you don't get any special reward for killing them, appart from health. So, yes, you can skip a lot of enemies if the level allows it and then you won't lose and recover your health. Difficulty comes in overpopulating the level with shots, but is hard for you to die. The lack of imagination and recurrent abuse of lesser enemies makes the levels from boring to indiferent.

Bosses are a little better. Some are interesting (such as bounty hunter or the tank guy), they have their patterns and you can learn them, predict their moves and shots and use it to your advantage. But some other ones are extremely easy (such as the centipede) or brutally difficult (metal gorilla, triple sisters). It's strange how the difficulty peaks and there is not always a clear way to fight them, with the fight resulting in you smashing button X. On the other hand, the final boss was the most interesting, with it's two phases.

But the game feels underwhelming. Shallow story; with bosses who don't have anything to say to you, appart from "I will kill you Strider, Huahahahaha"; not very interesting level layout (smash button X while running); repetitive combat; and some boss fights which were frankly a torture.

A very standard game. Why not play an awesome game instead?

43632790.review:
This is still one of the most enjoyable (and underrated) platformers I've played in ages.  

Polished, stylish and satisfying. Also quite a challenge toward the end. It only just feels like I'm finishing the Game after well over 10 hours playtime. I thought I was nearing the end and then discovered there is another task, another Boss to fight and another skill to unlock. It's one of 'those' Games.

There are a whole load of bosses and they're fairly varied and fun to fight (if sometimes a little easy). Enemies are satisfying to Kill and using the Sword feels as powerful and cool as in the original Strider.
I think I've counted over twenty different Bosses so far; all with individual introduction screens.

Map design is pretty open and at times this can lead to some confusion in finding objectives. Once you learn to read the map's indicator this isn't really a problem and back-tracking can be kept to a minimum. 

Runs well and looks pretty damn good for its age and budget, with some nice effects and 3D work.

Add the fact this is often on sale or in a bundle and you have yourself a proper little bargain here.

43602480.review:
[h1]Strider is an ninja action Metroidvania that takes a while before it gets fun. The early hour is a bit dull - while it plays like a decent old school action game, there's nothing that sets it apart besides the stylish character and super fast attacks. It wasn't until the boss fight with the flying mercenary that combat became a little more fun and you finally unlock the ability to reflect basic bullets.[/h1]

In Metroid games, the excuse that the protaganist doesn't have all of her abilities from the start of the game is that Samus doesn't have the authorization to use all her weapons. A paper thin excuse, but an excuse nonetheless. This game has no excuse other than "because its a game and we need an excuse for progression and game longevity". [b]Why does a Ninja have to unlock his Kunai from an underground black market dealer after beating a boss? Why does Strider have to unlock a slide kick ability? Why is he not able to do his ground slam ability when he gets his kick ability?[/b] Getting some of the basic moves in this game would be like not being able to get a side arm, main gun and grenades in a first person shooter until you kill some bosses with your knife. I feel like it really drags the game down and had I gone with my first impression, I would have quit this game before the fun happened. (I almost did).

Regardless, the game picks up with more challenging play afterwards. I feel the movement/jumping is a bit "too slidey/slippery" so I died jumping around traps when I felt like I shoudn't have (though there are techniques to get a better handle of Hiryu's speedy movemnt). It seems the game is designed for you tank some damage when running head first into enemy loaded hallways, as it doesn't seem quite possible to dodge or reflect all the bullets that will come your way. The world is generally filled with healing pods though, and enemies drop small bits of of health and energy, so a decently skilled player shouldn't die too much if at all. (Even pitfalls and traps don't insta-kill you and instead quickly respawns you with a small health loss).

Presentation wise, the game has a nice clean look and the sword effect looks really nice in high speed. Up close character textures are a bit bad when the camera closes up on Strider (when he gets a new ability for example) There's an extremely annoying propoganda message from the boss that repeats ad infinitum until you reach a certain point - not do you only have to constatly hear the same lines over and over, but the lines are captioned in a bar that takes about the bottom 1/8th of the screen, which covers up the player characters and elements of the world including enemies, items and passages. Music is fine, but forgettable. There's apparently an ability to customize Strider's appearance, but four hours in and I haven't unlocked any other costumes. I assume you unlock them after completing the game and I severely doubt I'll comeback to the game as I'm clearing my backlog, making this useless to me. And the non-player characters are very typical, flat personalities with nothing to really love about them.

[h1] Strider takes about an hour and a half before it gets fun in my opinion, so be ready for that. I don't feel like you're missing anything by not playing this, though, if you never have played the classic Strider games, then you probably would like to at least know how it feels to slash a sword half a dozen times in a second. You can skip Strider, but give it some time and it becomes a solid Metroidvania[/h1]

42645813.review:
I loved the Arcade, NES and Genesis Striders. I had the Playstation one at some point but don't think I ever actually played it.

Sooooooo... this one reminds me of a cross between the Arcade and NES versions. Graphics, enemies and fast combat like the arcade, and the little bit of metroidvania that is "similar" to the NES version. Plays and feels much more like an arcade game, though.

Firstly, as someone else said in a review, the combat gets boring really fast. You get other plasmas (weapon types) and some throwing knives and stuff, but in the end it all comes down to mashing buttons. The reason for this is that most of the enemies are bullet sponges. Worse than in any actual arcade game I played as a kid. I mean fuuuuuck... c'mon. You also have a charge attact that you HAVE TO use against some shielded enemies, especially towards the beginning of the game. The problem is the charge takes like two or so seconds, and waiting can open you to a lot of cheap hits.

The platforming is overall good and imaginative, but some parts will reeeeeeeeeeeeeeally piss you off. If you are like me and scream and cuss when you're frustrated at a game, you might want to keep the door closed if you live with someone.

This game is really too long in my opinion. For the type of game it is, a metroidvania shoehorned into an arcade game, it needs to be three or four hours, tops. Because it's more an arcade game, so the length should correspond moreso to that genre than the other.

Honestly, if there's one thing I could change about this game, it would be the bullet sponge enemies. If there wasn't so much of that, this game would be infinitely more fun. I mean, I'd rather see more enemies than fewer that are artificially padded out.

I've had a few glitches in this game, causing me to have to restart. They mostly revolved are waves of enemies that attack you not completely spawning. For instance, I was in the tower at the end of the game, and you're basically doing an enemy gauntlet riding up an elevator. First two times it works fine... I ride up, I die, it starts over. The third time, however, as I'm going up, I kill a few waves of enemies then... nothing. The elevator keeps "moving" but nothing else spawns so that it can proceed. So I'm just stuck in the animation of an elevator going up. "Ok" I say, going to end game and reload the save like the few times before. But this time it starts me AT THE DOOR TO THE FUCKING TOWER AGAIN!!! I got pissed and shut the damn thing off. 

Fuck this glitchy game. I mean, you're already making me kill tons of bullet sponges, and now you want to give me a royal "FUCK YOU" yet again when I'm almost done?!? 

Yeah, I'll beat the game. But it sure won't be tonight. Damn thing.......... *grumble grumble*

You can usually pick this up for dirt cheap now. You can try it at a heavy discount, but honestly this only brings back any nostalgia by way of the visual aesthetics and the music. The game is sub-par, as much as I hate to admit it. Anyone looking for Strider should play one of the older iterations and leave this one alone.

42173588.review:
Strider (2014) is a Hack'n Slash 2,5D side scroller game developed by Double Helix and Capcom Osaka, it also stands as a reboot of the franchise. The game has been published on PC, Playstation 3, Playstation 4, Xbox 360 and Xbox One.

The plot tells the tale of Strider Hiryu, an assassin sent to Kazakh City with a mission to kill the despotic dictator Meio. Our experienced ninja proceeds through hordes of robotic guards and bounty hunters, helps the local resistance and eliminate the most important officers in Kazakh forces. Nothing really original and the characters are not interesting, just another excuse to slash some guys. Took me 4 hours 37 minutes to clear.
Gameplay includes mechanics inspired by Original Strider and Strider 2, when Hiryu's design has been based on his look from Marvel vs Capcom 3:Fate of Two Worlds. On start of his quest our protagonist has only 2 base attacks, however pushing the game progression gives us upgrades, new skills and weapons just as in other Metroidvania games. The cast of enemies keep increasing, some of them may be hard on first try but later they become easier as you acquire new gear and learn how to use it. Your best friend will be the Cypher, which after unlocking allows Strider to perform charge attacks and later even perform a double jump and dash, there are also 3 other variants that increase the damage, freeze the enemies or give you magnetic blades, but they are acquired later. Bosses are not really special, they can surely be challenging sometimes but not very intense, some of them even dissapoint. The map keeps hidden collectibles such as big medkits, unlockable challenges, intel and upgrades that increase our stats, also there are some secret weapons droped by fallen Striders.
The map contains many hidden content but also many doors leading to different locations, after getting the right gear you can always backtrack to get all the stuff you have missed. There is no denying that Kazakh is not any worse than Dracula Castle from Castlevania games in case of design, locations are preety various in case of views, the climate is definetely well preserved.
Soundtrack have really surprised me to be honest, it is not loud but if you listen carefully you will recognise many remixes of classic Strider tracks, including the very best Kazakh Theme plus some other good sounds really fitting the action. To be honest I haven't expected such a quality in this case.
Technically the graphics are preety typical for 2014, nothing astonishing but does not hurt your eyes either, but there is one annoying glitch, in one place Strider has been stuck inside the textures forcing me to restart from last checkpoint. Nothing really problematic so you will not have any trouble I think.

The game is great, I can assure you, but not as good as classic ones. The plot is very predictible and does not give any feelings, just an excuse.Gameplay lacks some challenge but works fine, soundtrack fits great but music might have been louder, bosses kinda dissapoint but they are good enough and there are almost no issues with it. I think that the game deserves a strong 7,9/10.

39839041.review:
[h1]Strider is a fun, precise platformer worthy of a successor to the classics[/h1]

With Mega Man 11 around the corner, I took a look back to the last platformer published by Capcom in 2014. That being the reboot of Strider Hiryu's titular platformer. There are a lot of things I could say about this game that make it so good but its not without its flaws.

[b]Gameplay[/b]

Compared to its predecessors, Strider's controls and gameplay are very polished and fast-paced. Works well and is very reflex heavy. I found the difficulty had a perfect curve, nothing was too hard until the last couple of hours. I had the most trouble on the mechanical gorilla but didn't do the last level which was apparently cheap af. I don't bother with final levels in difficult games like this anyway.

The bosses are probably the most fun I've had for a while. They're a perfect challenge for me, not too hard but maybe a little frustrating later on. There were a couple I found a little on the cheap side most definitely but regardless, they are all great boss fights for sure.

Overall, don't come in expecting a cakewalk but among the perfectly fast paced design of the controls and the goddamned amazing bosses makes the gameplay really a cut above the rest! Maybe with a few minor to major frustrations, especially in the latter parts of the game.

9/10

[b]Presentation[/b]

I'll try to look objectively as hard as it is. Being a sucker for futuristic cities and anime-style character designs. Honestly, as much as I love the character designs and the way they designed the cities the artwork isn't Strider's strongest point.

I find the lack of facial expressions a little laughable and the Wind sisters didn't appeal to me as much as I hoped they would. Their models were a little ugly. That's my biggest gripe with the visuals, everything else is good... but not [i]great[/i]. The backgrounds and level designs are quite good. I loved the consistent motifs for sure. The temple especially is very nice looking. I didn't reeallly fall in love with the graphics in general besides a few things.

Story is barebones af but as someone who doesn't play for the story it doesn't bother me. Just be warned tho, it gets a little confusing as there isn't much to sink in cutscene-wise.

7/10

[b]Overall[/b]

It's a great game, period. It maybe frustrating and sorta bland but among the fast gameplay and a plentiful of content, I recommend it. If you like fun bosses and a sense of adventure, by all means this is brilliant in that way. Don't come expecting in-depth storytelling and a nice walk in the park, or you'll be very disappointed.

[h1]8/10[/h1]

39639631.review:
[b]Why am I playing this, again?[/b]

Yeah, that question was plaguing me for a bit while playing strider, and I... still don't really know.
Sure, the game is pretty, very well made in the visual aspect and sounds quite pleasant. That was adding to the experience. Or would, if there was much of an experience here to begin with.

See, most of the time in Strider is spent on combat and exploration. Now, that would be nice if these elements were good but they... really aren't. Rewards for exploration are very dull, sometimes an upgrade, mostly 'intel', which basically means pieces of lore scattered about. Now, the ridiculous part is that it seems like those collectibles are the only way to understand what this game tries to be about, aside from a ninja going after some generic totalitarian state. For the first hour, the characters don't say a thing, it takes close to 1.5h to even be informed about your main character's name. Miniature pieces of exposition are dropped through dialogue, but a lot of it is just generic, annoying and repetitive "evil totalitarian speaker messages".
Anyway, what else about exploration? Nothing. You can see everything on the map, it is most of the time clear that you will need some kinda upgrade to snoop around further, and that is mostly it. Not much of a sense of wonder and discovery, even less of a desire to get more, since rewards are so mediocre.

The combat isn't better, possibly worse. Now, early disclaimer, I played the game on Normal, since that should be the difficulty by which one can judge a game properly. And on Normal, Strider is... ridiculously easy when it doesn't cheap-shot you. Your character's ability to dodge fire well is close to zero, you will just eat bullets all the time, but that doesn't even matter! Killing enemies gives health, health is scattered in abnormal amounts throughout the game as well. It is like the game knows you have to be healed to an obscene degree because you can't do anything about the fact that the bullets will fly, you will get hit and the enemies know where you are before you can see them!
And that last part showcases a bigger problem, which is the camera and visual cues. First of all, the camera is so close that many times you will walk into an obstacle because you didn't see it before moving. This is merely frustrating because those just play death animation and penalise you with minimal health loss. What is worse are enemies shooting you, optionally shooting you from another building and similarly optionally shooting you from behind the foreground. And in the latter two cases, you will likely run face-first into these enemies and get smacked in the face by them.
All of these issues are further dragged down the mud by the fact that Strider has two attacks, neither of which are satisfying to use nor carry any impact, and the bosses. Though calling these clowns 'bosses' is an overstatement, usually, they are just a partial inconvenience and a time-waster, unable to kill you unless this is the first time you encounter a given type of their attack or if their blabber covers the [i]visual cues of their own attack[/i]. They are real and annoyingly easy pushovers. Ironically, that means they fit perfectly into absolutely meaningless combat of the game.

There is something to be said about slick controls and a great feeling of freedom through very versatile movement system; you can climb anything, jump over enemies while slashing at them and so on, but the feel of being a ninja vanishes when all you do is eat bullets and get hit by stupid things.

[b]In conclusion, it is not like Strider is a bad game, but it is so blatantly mediocre and lacking any substance to anything within the game, that you are better off not wasting your time on it.[/b]

If you're like me and you've tried the demo for PS3 (also on PS4 and Xbox 360 I believe), you probably thought, "meh, seems alright". I got it as part of a Humble Bundle, and I'm glad I got it.

The biggest problem I find is the first few hours being a bit bland. There's no payoff for killing grunts, which is too bad, because had there been money or points or something to be it wouldn't feel so pointless killing so many of these weak enemies. And for the first few hours, with just the regular sword attack to use, gameplay gets pretty repetitive.

However, once you're about 3 hours in, the powerups and new abilities kinda rush in, and then it starts getting fun, opening up different fighting tactics and accessible areas. The game plays pretty well, control is good, visuals are alright, sound is not annoying. Boss fights are pretty good as well.

It's too bad the game plays so flat at the beginning, because I can see lots of people giving up before it improves. It's not a particularly long game to begin with, but better pacing would have helped keep interest in the bland opening act.

38168557.review:
[h1]"Disobediance will be punished. Revolution will be crushed."[/h1]
[i]- General Mikiel, delivering a motivational speech.[/i]

Some ninjas prefer the path of stealth, fading into the shadows like Kevin Spacey's career. Other ninjas prefer the path of violence, their destruction of their noodles striking fear into the waiter's eyes.

You are Strider Hiryu. Your path is to pelt pigeons at people's faces.

Strider is the fifth entry in the Strider franchise, that began with Strider and whose latest entry is Strider. Now I know that can get confusing, so for clarity's sake I'm going to call this one Strider. 

It's a Metroidvania, which boils down to "there's a couple of colour coded doors, come back when you're rocking their fashion sense". Touted as a retelling of the classic Strider story (the other Strider) I'm still not entirely sure what the story is. The wikia says that Earth got sucker punched by a dictator and Hiryu here is the youngest agent sent to go sort it out, who drew the short straw as it was the only one left.

Most I can say about the story is that Hiryu speaks with a comically thick Japanese accent, which is novel to hear. 

[h1]"What do you know of Striders, prisoner?"[/h1]
[i]- The Strider, talking about Striders[/i]

For the gameplay, it's well defined; about half of it can be defined as good. For the good half, Hiryu can icepick his way along any surface; overhangs and small hills are no match for his mighty tools. For the rest of your amazing platforming moves, you get a double-jump and a dash. Don't let your jaw hit the floor too hard. It's solid and the platforming challenges are the highlight of the game. After you're done, there's these "Beacon Run" time trials that I absolutely suggest going for.

Once you've passed the highlight, you come to the combat. Which is not the highlight. See, Hiryu swings his immasculated toothpick as fast as you can hit the button, which has the effect of it feeling like an itty bitty tooth-cleaning device. Weak, ineffectual, unsatisfying, and roughly half the game.

Course, said toothpick is spiced up a little by the elements - Cold, Reflect, Gravity and Explosions, the classical Greek ones you're used to - and the introduction of "options" that involve throwing pigeons at people's faces for significant damage or cats for paltry damage, but it never ascends beyond combat that's just a chore. 

A launcher and a slide are there if you really feel the need to make your chip damage slightly less useful.

[h1]"Strider, you have been marked a danger to the state. Surrender, or face the consequences."[/h1]
[i]- Solo, not the drink.[/i]

That's on Hard, mind. On Normal - I didn't even touch Easy - enemies dies almost instantly, going too far in the other direction to braindeadville. I mentally clocked out either way.

Now, apart from that core combat, the world is nicely contextualized with platforms that double as rooftops, balconies, prison meeting areas, your mother's secret fetish dungeon, et cetera. Combined with a nicely paced OST that's fairly experimental, and it's a 2.5D game that looks great - like finding a unicorn in hen's teeth.

Just a shame it's boring to play. 

Going back over fully completing Strider, it's just not a game I'd recommend. For every decent aspect, and there are a few, I just keep circling back to how empty and listless the combat fundamentally is. 

I'd advise you go check out some other Metroidvanias. I don't recommend Strider, but it is totally playable if you're here for that.

37966818.review:
I'm a huge Megaman X fan so this game is right up my alley. It's overall a fun game but I feel like it could have used some more polish in terms of presentatioin.

Here are some of my frustrations while playing the game.

---No Intro---
Some people would see this as a plus because they'd wanna' drop into the game and just start playing. I count this as a negative as I want some context before I play. A minute worth of intro would have been nice.


---Soundtrack is lacking---

I'm not asking for an epic score but it would be nice to have some Capcom-like soundbites from the 90's.I mentioned before that I'm a huge Megaman X fan and this is one thing that would have made Strider's fun experience into a memorable one.  

---Some Glitches---
Sometimes the door animations won't play as they're already open when i enter the room. This would be fine if I could walk through it but no. The game still reads it as a closed door thus rendering it inaccessible. This has happened only 3 times in my 9 hour run of the game.

It often suffers from slow down and I've read that it's happened to everyone so I have no idea if it's cuz of bad optimization or my laptop is just crap. haha 

Steam version may not be the version to pick up.

---Enemy variation---
This is can be taken as either positive or negative. Most of the enemies are soldiers with guns and robots. Sometimes they use different guns. I say that this can be taken as positive as it does feel like you're fighting against a military force instead of a wacky funhouse. 

Now, I'm moving onto the positives.

+++Fluid Play Style+++
Any of Strider's abilities will work on almost every enemy. At first, your options are limited, but in time you'll find abilities that you can stick with throughout the entire game. You can play aggressive like I did and use the fire upgrade the most or you can use the ice upgrade to incapacitate enemies. Etc.

+++Awesome Visuals+++
Character models might look like late PS2 era but the environments look beautiful.  

+++Huge Map+++
The 2D map here is done almost perfectly. It annoys me because it's so close... Megaman ZX and ZXA could take notes from this 'cuz, man, I can actually understand the map here. It's still not as good as Castlevania's maps though because fast travel is not done well in this game. Good luck getting all the collectible stuff here and backtracking.

+++Hiryu is fucking cool+++
It's hilarious how this guy doesn't give a shit outside of being a ninja. You'll know what I'm talking about when you finish the game. Once the credit's roll after the final fight, watching strider get out of danger is amazing to me.

Overall, good game. It's got a weak start but once you get the ball rolling, it feels pretty damn good to climb around the environments and cut your way though swaths of soldiers.

36616584.review:
There is a resurgence for the metroidvania genre and somehow it's good (like Hollow Knight) but in Strider it's just plenty boring in my opinion. I have played 3h or so and I have hard to get back to the game so much it's repetitive.

Strider used to be a fast 2D fast action platformer that you can finish in 1 or 2 hours filled with challenges. In the new Strider you will need 5 to 8 hours where you're going to look for switches, doors to unlocks, options, upgrades, etc... As soon as you finished unlocking something, you have to move next to the next thing to unlock. Quite linear overall.

For what I played I had 1 interesting boss for 3 boring ones and 2 okay mini bosses. The enemies are easy and repetitive, they kill you only when you're swarmed by them. There are a few interesting platform sections here and there but you spend more time exploring and killing easy enemies.

The music is excellent in some places but most of the time you get an ambient music not special at all. The concept arts look amazing with a great depth (you can see a gigantic city which reminds me of Blade Runner), I wish they did the game in 2D because in 3D they made it look flat, boring, without any depth.

I would suggest the game only to people who wants to relax and kill time i the couch. But there are so many better metroidvanias out there, I wouldn't suggest that one in particular.

35966234.review:
Many moons ago, I came into possession of a new game for my Sega Genesis. After rushing home, popping it into my console and turning on the power, it was then I was almost immediately treated to one hell of a show. There I was, gliding into an enemy base, sirens blazing, only then to start flipping majestically through the air while making short work of the enemies that were foolish enough to cross my path. This was my first encounter with the Strider series, and safe to say it was a pretty lasting one.  

Fast forward to this latest addition to the series, then, and it’s a delight to see that everything that made Strider cool back when I was a kid has made the jump to today.  That feeling of being a legendary ninja is re-ignited at the very beginning of the game, as you fly in yet again with the instantly recognisable theme song blaring away in the background, and easily manages to sustain itself from there.  

You see, this is action thrown at you at an almost frantic pace. There’s a seemingly endless swarm of enemies always attacking you, and it’s up to you to flip and dash around them... Or, better still, simply go to town and cut them all to ribbons, with the thrill of murdering everything in a room without even stopping for breath being an oh-so-satisfying one. Start sinking your teeth deeper into the Metroid-vania style gameplay, and it only gets better. You’ll unlock items that can deflect bullets back at your foes, set them on fire, or (if all else fails) simply obliterates them via a spirit eagle that you can summon to do your dirty work. Whatever your choice, such systematic destruction never gets old. 

It’s not just endless foot soldiers that end up falling to your blade, however.  Things truly come to a head when it comes to fighting the game’s numerous bosses, which challenge you to take your skills and apply them to battles that are (for the most part) challenging yet fair. Learning the attack patterns of each boss, deftly dodging them and then unloading your own assault to come out on top is a process that is very pleasantly rewarding... Yet no matter the combat situation, there’s many a moment that just feels cool, and you’ll want to keep going just to try and generate that next cool moment for yourself.

It’s annoying, then, that some of the game’s design seems to primarily exist to slap you cruelly back down to Earth. For instance, far too many enemies have attacks that can stun you momentarily or knock you down for a second or two.  Not only does this break the flow of the action far too often, but you’re so vulnerable once you’re in a stunned state that it’s not uncommon to end up trapped in a cycle where you’re knocked down again the second you stand back up. The same holds even more true with the traps mounted on the many walls you have to climb, with a single brush against a spinning saw blade or similar obstacle sending you tumbling off the wall like an ungraceful idiot. You will encounter many a moment where you’ve nearly reached the peak of a grand ascent, only for a tiny miscalculation to send you crashing into an obstacle and plummeting down to right where you started. It’s something that will hinder your progress so much, you’ll start to wonder why the enemy hasn’t just plastered such obstacles on every flat surface possible.

There’s also some weird level design in play that doesn’t really fit the aesthetic of you being an unstoppable ninja. The most glaring of these comes about halfway through the game, where three large water valves block the path you wish to proceed down. Two open up easily enough, but opening the third sees you travelling halfway across the world to obtain an item that only then removes this barrier. It’s a minor criticism, I concede - the game has to hinder your progress via some method - but the contrast between being a screaming whirlwind of death one second and then some sort of weird errand boy the next is still a tiny bit jarring. 

It doesn’t help that the map you’re travelling around also feels a tiny bit uninspired, with only two or three little areas sticking in my memory when I try and cast my mind back to where the adventure took me. The rest of the world remains distinctly forgettable, a bland mix of grey buildings and unremarkable landscapes that do little to spark the imagination. If you’re hoping there’s an exciting storyline in place that can perhaps compensate for this, then you’re sadly mistaken – while the characters themselves look cool, the smattering of cut scenes they play a role in never really explain anything in regards to what’s going on. Put simply – you’re a good guy, you’re trying to kill the bad guy, and things don’t really go anywhere beyond that. If you’re looking for a compelling tale to captivate you, you’ve come to the wrong place. 

Still, even though I’ve spent as long critiquing the game's faults as I have done pointing out its strengths, none of them even come close to destroying the sense of joyous carnage the game manages to capture. You might be frustrated in one moment, but give it a few more moments and you’ll most likely be back on the adrenaline rush where it feels like nothing can stand in your path. We’ve come on great strides (Ha ha) since my first encounter with the series, then, but this version of Strider is still one that is well worth checking out.

35702125.review:
Not an especially good action game, and not an especially good Metroidvania, Strider is a functional but largely unimpressive game. For all the neon lights and Saturday morning cartoon monologues, it's frankly just kind of bland.

In terms of action gameplay, the camera is simply too close. Much of the game consists of being shot at by characters just off screen or jumping towards the only visible platform. The bullets are blessedly slow, and many of your attacks have a healthy bit of range to them, but at a certain point it'd be nice to feel like you can set - or even completely understand - the terms that you're fighting on.

And on the exploration front, while the map UI and ability set feel very Metroid-inspired, the level design can't keep up. The platforming itself does get interesting at a few points, but the game has you hurtling constantly forward. There's no gradually expanding your familiarity with a place or finding new ways to advance; new mobility options just let you go back and collect unimportant collectables just off the main path.

Bottom line, Strider is fine, but there are plenty of better options out there.

35700289.review:
Well...

[b]Graphics:[/b] This game looks really pretty. Gorgeous. It uses the hardware Ambient Occlusion from your video card in very delightful ways, making most everything pop or blend in, depending on the situation. I love the reflection effects - yummy! Lots of great use of lighting or not throughout. Color choice is dull and cold, but the colorful bright lighting in many spots make up for it. Overall, the color choices evoke excellently the despair of the times you, as Hiryu, find yourself in. [b]9/10[/b]

---+---

[b]Sound:[/b] Not too throwback-y, and very well done. Voice acting is something to get used to, but Hiryu's okay as well as some others. Adds to the satisfaction of gameplay when one is slicing/dicing/making Julienne Fries out of the enemies. Very atmospheric sound design and very good orchestral/rock soundtrack. [b]9/10[/b]

---+---

[b]Gameplay:[/b] VERY satisfying. Stressful day? Slice up some of Grand Master Meio's lackey soldiers, cause some machinery to not work anymore, cause other machinery to go "boom" - in general, get that frustration of the day out here while knowing that you are contributing to a freer, less militant Kazakhstan in the progress. Or just go nuts with your Cypher - that also works, too. (The author of this review does not condone violence to anyone unless for good self-defense reasons - in short, play nice.)

Hiryu has so much ability to kick all sorts of can (the tin variety, too ;) ) in this game that at first you think you won't need the power-ups. This game is surprising that way and, while you can only play as Hiryu, so much gets unearthed as you play - unlocking color schemes and finding extra challenges along the way, should you deviate from the missions even a little bit or making a betweener before battling a Boss or five. I have to say, though: exploiting the new moves you acquire to achieve certain "goodies" can be cryptic if you don't know how they initially behave - keep that one in mind. 

HOWEVER, when you do acquire the powerups you need, they won't be too hard to use to progress throughout the game, so don't sweat it! :) [b]8/10[/b]

---+---

[b]Final Score: 9/10[/b]

---+---

[b]Opinion:[/b] If you are even remotely aware of the original Strider Hiryu games of decades past, or are up for something new pretty and fresh, atmosphere and gameplay-wise, do yourselves a favor and purchase this one - please don't pass it up! You'll make Hiryu sad... 

but seriously, try this game, at least. You might like it.

35581704.review:
Seems Metroidvania genre gained another fan.

Strider is one of those games that requires usage of all possible tools you get throughout the game if you want to gain success especially on the highest difficulty. I had a blast with this game, ripping through enemies combining and mixing attacks/special attacks/throwable kunais while dodging incoming attacks. 

Pros:
[list]
[*] Fast paced combat. Dont try to play this game while everyone in the house sleeps, cause you will smash those gamepad buttons A LOT and LOUD. Combat is non-stop, there are barely a few small areas where you run forwards without facing enemies.
[*] Variety of enemies. Quite enough variety to force you to use different tactics and attacks
[*] Bosses. Excluding 'Winds' every other boss has unique patterns. Fighting bosses was the most enjoyable part of the game
[*] Various locations. Same as with bosses each location is unique, in terms of visuals and traversal elements you have to take in count while just moving or fighting.
[/list]

Cons: 
For me, none. 25 hours went like nothing for me.

Strong recommendation both for metroidvania fans and casual players, 10/10.

35512516.review:
Well balanced gameplay and slick visuals define Strider. Its Metroidvania design, scan lines reminiscent of CRT TV and the silly, run-of-the-mill good vs. evil story evoke nostalgia of the '80s and '90s.

The dystopian setting offers a variety of areas influenced by science fiction, cyberpunk and the Iron Curtain. In general, the graphics are beautiful and polished with an atmosphere fitting its respective area. Only a few scenes that shine a spotlight on the characters reveal static, comic-like faces. Clearly though, Strider is not a game with important character interaction, dialogue or even the slightest need to engage in the story. The music and sound effects are light, with less bass and more treble, yet crisp and generally underline the swiftness of Strider Hiryu.

Although fiddly in the beginning, the controls are precise and responsive to the point that even changing direction in mid-air is not only animated well but also happens instantly with just the right feeling of control. The enemies and bosses have balanced attack patterns that later on grow in complexity and need to be faced with consideration rather than full offence button mashing.

Strider hits the nail on the head and offers a solid, highly polished platformer.

35234024.review:
El juego es una maravilla, rapido y fluido, muy adictivo. Es un juego de la vieja escuela, tipico mata mata de recreativa 
 pero con graficos y conceptos modernos como la mejora de armas permanete, de vida, de energia, mejoras en los movimientos, etc.
También tiene sus contras y es que ademas de conseguir mejoras fisicas y de armamento diré que ese concepto a la hora de rejugarlo es algo que le rebota en contra pues cuando te lo terminas no puedes volver a jugar con todas las mejoras conseguidas sino que empizas desde el principio sin nada, tal y como cuando lo empezaste la primera vez, lo cual es decepcionante, ya que sin las mejoras el juego pierde mucho y hay muchos lugares del mapa que no puedes accder sin esas mejoras.
El juego empieza a disfurtarse conforme el personaje va obteniendo mejoras, es ahí cuando realmente disfrutas.
Los bosses no son excesivamente dificiles solo hay que cogerles el truco hay alguno algo mas complicado, en mi caso <<solo>> me parecio el más duro. me mató 4 veces. Pero me gustó el reto que supuso.
Al principio se hace algo mas complejo ya empiezas con muy poquita vida luego la cosa cambia.
La historia es como la de cualquier juego de finales de los 80' o principio de los 90', malo malisimo que quiere dominar el mundo. Fin.
El arte conceptual es una maravilla, Las animaciones son muy de ainme y la banda sonora una maravilla también.
A mi en un amd 8350 y una rx460 de 2gb y 8 gb de ram me va perfecto nada de crasheos, ni tirones, muy muy fluido como ya comenté al principio.
Si os gustaban estos juego tipico de recreativas de matar a todo ser viviente y algo de plataformeo os recomiendo jugarlo (estos juegos en oferta o en humble son lo que te sorprenden muy gratamente, en mi caso adquirí un humble por el dmc y me encuentro con este tesoro :o) aunque para rejuagarlo en mi caso deberá pasar algun tiempo. 
El juego no es largo pero considero que para este estilo tiene una duración addecuada (en mi caso segun steam unas 10 horas segun el juego 6 y pico todo depende del nivel de dificultad, de tu habilidad y de lo que explores el mapa) y una buena cantidad de bosses y de enemigos diferentes. Hay muchas cosas para explorar y recomiendo intentar coger todas las mejoras, las de vida y energia sobre todo.

34714287.review:
This isn't even my type of game (like, at all), or so I thought. Polished gameplay, good balance of challenge, great port, and a big thumbs up for the art.

[h1]Buy, wait for discount, or pass?[/h1]

[b]Wait for discount[/b] unless a fan of the genre or franchise.

Slow start, then an explosion of fun on second level, which is called "Kazakh City" and is artistically far deeper than I expected from a platformer. The level felt like it was made by very young and passionate people. The 'art' is tightly intertwined with the gameplay, which is new to me. Basically an immersive platformer? Wow. And it also feels like it was made by designers different from those who worked on the NPC's and powerups :) The latter feel rather generic and I can't really place them anywhere, they just...glow and stuff? I guess? But it's cool because due to them being the same throughout you learn to ignore them, blend them out. Still, I don't like the design of the protagonist, and that I couldn't blend out.

If you like me have no idea what Metroidvania means, here's a C/P from wikipedia:

[i]"'Metroidvania' is [...] a platforming game that features a single large, interconnected map, generally with discrete rooms or sections. Not all areas of this map are available at the start, often requiring the player to obtain an item (such as a weapon or key) or a new character ability to remove some obstacle blocking the path forward. Often, this item is protected by a boss character, providing story-driven challenges throughout the game. Maps are non-linear, and often require the player to traverse the map multiple times during the course of the game. Weaker monsters will inhabit other parts of the level, re-spawning when the player revisits those rooms, and often can be defeated to gain health, ammunition, or experience points."[/i]

Basically, it's a platformer where you are not directly forced to follow a certain path, but will definitely be revisiting areas to progress further once you've obtained a power-up that gives you more access (like a stronger hacking skill in Fallout 4, or whatever). But in this game there are a lot of intelligent camera views, so I'd rather overall tag it an action game than a platformer.

Remember when games used to just be mindnumbingly fun?

This 2D action sidescroller is just that... fun! No need for complex controls, spending hours on finding the THE best specs and gear. No grinding or painful bosses which require you to learn the attack pattern by heart in order to advance. Nope. Just press forward and hack&slash your way through waves of enemies. Effortlessly collect power-ups which make the hack&slash even more fun! For the achievement whores out there, there are even a couple of collectable which require you to backtrack to previously visited places and use your newly acquired abilities to get that one collectible which you just couldn't reach at the beginning of the game.

The story itself is not very compelling, but it doesn't need to be!

The only downside I saw in my playthrough is that after picking up certain power-ups everything becomes... too easy. It's still fun but making it at least somewhat challening would be even more fun. After this you just spam that one ability over and over again which pretty much decimates all types of enemies even though you're supposed to alter between different abilities which offer some advantage over certain enemy types.

Other than that, I enjoyed this game so much! Games that are actually fun to play -- what a rarity these days!

34424856.review:
Qué decir de este juego... Hay juegos que me divierten, hay juegos que me entretienen... pero pocos juegos como Strider han conseguido atraer tanto mi atención.

Es complejo valorar, con los juegos de hoy en día, un juego que claramente tiene mecánicas de dos botones. No es ningún misterio que los botones que vas a fundir con este juego son la A y la X y los demás solo en ocasiones. Y es normal, viniendo de un juego original cuya consola solo tenía dos botones.

Pero eso no le quita el ser un juego de los que ya no hacen. De machacar botones como un loco. De mecánicas simples, saltar, correr, matar. Con jefes a la vieja usanza, algunos más fáciles que otros, pero los ha habido que realmente han sido un verdadero estorbo.

A algunos les parecerá que un juego de estos es demasiado fácil, o que un juego con mecánicas de dos botones es absurdo, pero a mí me parece que todo lo que carece de complejidad lo ha ganado en jugabilidad.

Y qué decir de una banda sonora excepcional. He de decir que he descubierto este juego antes de jugar el original de NES, pero he escuchado ambas bandas sonoras y creo que el trabajo hecho en este remake rinde honores al título original sin lugar a duda.

Y este último argumento creo que sirve para aquellos que piensen que este juego es valorado solo por los que sienten nostalgia por el título de NES o arcade. Este juego ha sido capaz de engancharme sin saber siquiera que era un remake, y lo ha hecho muy bien.

Poniéndonos técnicos, es una lástima que sea un juego gráficamente exigente para ser un sidescroller. Mi ordenador es gama media-baja y no puedo disfrutarlo a 1080, e incluso en 768 algunas partes con muchos efectos tienen caída de FPS, aunque normalmente sí que va fluido a esa resolución.

Si te gustaría volver a la época que los juegos se reducían a dos botones que había que machacar a lo bestia, sin perder unos buenos gráficos y un juego moderno, dale una oportunidad a este juego. 15 euros y estando de oferta de vez en cuando, realmente es una ganga.

34274316.review:
Excellent (must buy)
Good
[h1] Average (maybe when on sale)  [/h1]
Avoid (not worth your time and money)
 
[h1] Summary	[/h1]
You play as Strider Hiryu as you infiltrate Kazakh city. Fast and fun 2D action platform game although many of it’s features are copied from other games or recycled from the other Strider games. Recommended on sale. Takes around 6 to 8 hours to finish.

[h1] Review [/h1]
This is a reimagining for the strider series where you play as a deadly sword wielding ninja. It does a good job at capturing the feel of the classic arcade game. It has responsive controls, maintains the unique wall climbing and offers a good mix of platforming and combat. While the arcade game had linear stages this uses the ever popular Metroid formula, with different themed areas, where progress is gated with weapon coded doors. However the game doesn’t focus on exploration. Your objective is signposted and you can follow a linear path with a minimum of backtracking if you do not want to collect hidden upgrades and secrets.

The presentation is faithful to the original with many remixed music tracks, sound effects and familiar enemy designs. Part of the greatness of the original was the art and world design and the nostalgia is a double edged sword here. This game simply doesn’t offer the same kind of surprises and global adventure. The areas of the game that aren’t direct copies of the original are rather drab with a few good set pieces such as boss battles thrown in. The city you explore is made of military and industrial districts which aren’t that thrilling.

The visuals can be very cluttered at times, especially later in the game, with lots of effects and bullets on screen. There are also too many upgrades for the run time. There are 4 types of sword, 3 active abilities, air dash and kunai. For a fast paced action platform game it can feel a little contrived to only switch weapon to activate switches or destroy shields.
The story lasts around 6 hours (more if you want to hunt down secrets) as well as offering unlockable challenge levels. Overall it’s solid, there are better 2D action or platform games out there, I would recommend it when it’s on sale.

33971650.review:
[h1] What is Strider? [/h1]

Strider was quite the popular arcade game from 1989 (with a sequel in 1999) that had you in the role of the titular ninja Strider. You moved fast, could double jump and cling to nearly every surface available. The game was punishingly difficult but rewarded memorization and fast reflexes. 

This Strider isn't a remake or remaster of those games, but a sort of reboot. Since our PC and consoles no longer have a quarter slot, the game is designed to stretch out your twitch skills more than your wallet. Still taking the role of Strider (well, [i]a[/i] Strider now named Hiryu), now you'll start pathetically weak and require various upgrades to progress.

[h1] How's the story? [/h1]

Set in a future time, in a pseudo-soviet communist dictatorship, you're trying to topple the shadowy leader behind the government: Grandmaster Meio. To do so, you'll need to infiltrate their headquarters. But with their advanced technology, well equipped troopers and numerous powerful allies, you need to find help in the form of allies and power-ups. Other than that, the story is pretty straightforward.

However, given how uncomplicated the story is, the game drags it on and on. The pacing of the game feels like it should have been a much much shorter game. When I felt I was at a boss that had to be near the end, I looked it up and that boss was the 1/3rd mark. Not that lots of content is bad, but the story telling doesn't match the pace of the game.

[h1] What about the techy stuff? [/h1]

Before discussing the tech behind the game, we have to set our expectations. The game was 15 dollars on launch. The graphics are well done, but do not expect an AAA experience. Models are well done across the board but the textures are a little on the blurry side during cut scenes.

The music in the game is totally awesome and makes me wish they sold it separately. The audio is clean and informative, with hits being clearly registered. Enemy sound is less telling, but you're so much faster than your foes it isn't really a component of gameplay.

Sadly, the music is almost inaudible during the game. I only noticed how awesome it was once I paused the game.

[h1] What will I be doing?  [/h1]

Each boss you come across generally protects a small golden console that gives you a new power. Plasma blades that cut through shields, dashing mechanics or flaming spirit dragons. Foes will start relatively easy to defeat, but over time each mini-boss you defeat becomes a normal troop that you'll fight. This will put your upgrades to good use, as without them those fights are what qualifies them as mini-bosses.

So you'll start being able to jump, slide and attack. Over time your attacks will get better, cutting through shields or gaining new abilities like using shuriken. Your jump becomes a double jump and the spirit animals that help you in combat will give you new ways to go through old maps. It's not quite a metroidvania but it has many elements that remind me of that genre.

Something I really enjoyed was the bosses. They all feel very very unfair at first, requiring multiple deaths to learn their patterns but each time you die, you end up a little further than before. That sense of 100% skill based progression was very very satisfying.

One sore point for me was the foes getting better as you do. They'll replace weaker foes with more difficult ones you come across and while that keeps the game challenging, I never felt a sense of progression against the common enemies, only bosses.

[h1] Should you buy it? [/h1]

At 15 dollars, for around 10-20 hours of gameplay, yes. Economically, the game is worth it. However if you're not a fan of difficult games then you might want to avoid it. The game isn't famously difficult but it doesn't hold your hand. If you die, it's because you messed up and you'll be starting from the last checkpoint you visited. Those are far apart, so you could be backtracking far and often. If that all sounds like an incentive to get better at the game and not die, then it's probably right up your alley.

[h1] Pros [/h1]
[list]
[*] Gameplay that feels skill based and rewarding.
[*] Soundtrack that rocks, when you can hear it.
[*] Boss battles that are really give the feeling that you're progressing.
[/list]

[h1] Cons [/h1]
[list]
[*] Poorly paced story that feels stretched to match the game length.
[*] Audio is asymmetric (your stuff is great, enemy sound is forgettable) and the soundtrack is [i]quiet[/i].
[*] Foes scale, robbing you of a feeling of progression against non-bosses.
[/list]

I'm not a fan of numbered ratings for games, so I'll leave you with this you will probably enjoy this game 
[list]
[*] If you want to like Metroidvania games but feel the back and forth is tedius.
[*] If you want a cheap game that is thick with content.
[*] If you want a challenge, but the Souls series is scary.
[*] If you like feeling like a fast paced future-ninja.
[/list]

33736126.review:
[h1] Nier Automata + Assassin Creed = Strider [/h1]

It's a good, short, and lightweight kind of hack and slash + platformer game. 

Pros: 
> Really amazing level design, everything is almost explorable. Also certain place requires certain powers to enter it, so you'll need to reenter the place later.
> Unlockable system. This thing, surely needed in every modern games. Modern games are lack of unlockable system because most of them are treated as a paid DLC. 
> Level boss are really good, reminds me most of the classics game that you can hit boss while they're in rest state. 
> Very lightweight. Most modern game will have about more than 8GB+ HDD Space. This game, only took 5GB for 5h gameplay (if you play story mode only).
> Good graphics, runs perfect 60FPS on GTX 1050 TI 

Cons:
> Controls are as retarded as Assassin's Creed. Sometimes you can stuck on a platform and refuse to jump. And sometimes, it can jump unexpectedly.
> Some enemies are really making frustration. You'll require few secs to charge to attack shielded enemy, but shielded enemy attacks you at the same time you finish recharge. Also, some enemies will throw you somekind of lasers / bomb that will make you fall down while jumping or climbing. This is really frustrating, because it's like "When the hell I'll reach above ?!" 

Conclusion:
If you like short action hack and slash platformer that can bring you nostalgic sensation, can grab this while on sale. This game is fun, also frustrating sometimes.

33502815.review:
I wasn't sure what to think when I initially saw this, but I gotta say, I'm impressed.  The TL;DR version of this would be something along the lines of it's a combination of Shadow Complex and Strider for the NES.  Still not sure what I mean?  Okay, so basically it's a metroidvania, meaning there are very light RPG elements a la finding perma-powerups and such throughout the levels as well as some fast travel elements and backtracking.

It's also 2.5D, which I know doesn't appeal to everyone, but it looks pretty fantastic to me.  Finally, I say Strider for the NES, because that version of Strider WAS actually a metroidvania.  If you're looking for a more arcadey version of Strider, there are plenty of other titles, but this one is full on metroidvania.  It's fun, frantic, over the top, and has a lot of references to characters in past versions of Strider.  A must for any oldschool Strider Hiryu fan!

-----------------------------------
summary:

Overall the game play is ok at best. It looks nice and controls somewhat decent, but running to point A to point B gets boring fast when fighting the same baddies seen in every other area.

32260436.review:
The ninja-quick review: A rollercoaster in both thrills and its odd pacing, Strider is a very fast paced Metroidvania that remembers mechanically a lot of what makes the original good while adding some new features and not getting -too- carried away with  it.

For a review more the length of the titular character's ridiculous scarf, I'll start with the negatives.  First off, the game is awkwardly paced and short.  I beat it in four hours and change, and four hours is the speedrun time- I certainly spent a fair amount of time dicking around as well.  There's a couple sections where you need to open specific doors or activate objects and the game takes you on a tangential objective.  One such situation actually has you go on no fewer than four tangential objectives at the same time, a cascading necessary sidequest involving multiple boss fights.  If anything feels like being given the runaround, it's this part of the game, but there's also some other points that feel like backtracking.  The difficulty is also a bit all over the place; if two enemies surround strider the game you can do almost nothing, but otherwise you're all but invulnerable.  Some of the special abilities are easy to forget about and a bit awkward, and the elemental switching is almost always a very black-and-white choice (since only one weapon type breaks the majority of shields and does like double damage).

There's also some things that are more middling.  Metroidvania format has its ups and downs.  There's a lot of secrets to collect, but almost none of them are even that helpful, and although it's kind of cool that the special kunai and dash elemental abilities are hidden, keeping them hidden means they can't be all that fantastic and sure enough they're pretty middling.  Another hit-and-miss thing is the art design.  It's as flashy as it should be, but the models sometimes make it difficult to determine what's a plaform or what's going on at all at times.  Finally, the music didn't really do anything for me, and the story/dialogue is straight out of console generation 4.

The good bits of Strider are the speed, breadth of movement and attack directions, the controls are awesome besides the fairly uneeded specials, there's exactly the right number of enemy types and bosses for the game's length and they're matched well to your abilities, bigass levels that are enjoyable to explore and some ridiculous setpieces to blow up.  If you want to play a fast platformer where you cut half the level and slide through robots by the dozen to get to crazy bossfights- I mean, it does it.  It does it really well.  I didn't find a single bug or stutter, nothing.  Fifteen bux is an okay price even with the length but it's gonna go on sale, and if this interests you at all you should get it then.

31260063.review:
Pretty solid modernized version of Strider with Metroid-like level progression, though I wouldn't consider it a fully fledged metroidvania game since exploration aspect in this game is pretty pale. Takes around 7 hours to 100%. Navigation outside of main objectives isn't very fun and there aren't any real points of interest besides color-coded locked doors which usually hide a power-up or concept art unlock.

Game itself is more combat oriented and that's where is shines. All animations are fast and don't cancel anything (e.g. you can jump, throw kunai and power up your slash at the same time), plus you get 4 different attack types that change how your combat moves behave, neither mode is a direct upgrade but instead they compliment each other (e.g. use reflective mode to reflect bullets while you run torwards the enemy, switch to magnetic mode and dash to stun them, and then switch to flame mode to finish the stunned enemy off). Most locked doors are opened by a dash so you don't have to pause while moving from area to area either. There are no pauses during movement or combat, it feels very streamlined and fast-paced.

Visuals are nice and clean, have a nice style (e.g. some effects like dust or explosions look more hand-drawn than realistic), but nothing to write home about. Enemies telegraph their shots and projectiles are very easy to see. Bosses make great use of projectiles, something you would see in old arcade games. Bosses in this game are in general very fun and challenging, and urge you to move a lot, unlike some other modern metroidvania games (*cough*Shadow Complex*cough*).

One thing that puzzles me is complete lack of facial animations during cutscenes. It's not noticable on Hiryu and some other characters that wear masks, but it looks very cheap on characters that don't.

Some issues with the game: Game is locked at 60 fps. You can't remap keys in-game, but you can do so by editing config files. Non-XInput controllers are supported only through third-party means (x360ce). Controls during segments that have non-standard gravity are just plain bad both on keyboard and controller, but these segments are rare and it doesn't ruin them completely.

30659026.review:
Pretty good 2d hack'n'slash metroidvania.

You run around several different locations hacking down enemies with your sword, killing bosses, and gaining upgrades that allow you to access previously inaccessible locations.  You'll start off weak and grow more powerful with every upgrade including more health, more energy, long range attacks, etc.  Enemies and bosses have tactics and weaknesses that you learn and exploit.  There's not really much of a story to the game, you're there to assassinate the baddie, that's pretty much it.  Characters aren't really explored and are cliche for the most part.  Expect the dialogue to be not so good.  Game is pretty much constant action/exploration which makes it enjoyable.

The game does have several issues.  The biggest is probably the wall grapple controls.  You can attach to almost every wall/ceiling in the game and move around.  Getting off of these can be problematic at times.  You'll press the jump button to detach and instead he'll keep on hanging there.  The game automatically moves you up platforms if you get to the edge of them instead of waiting for a prompt from you to do so.  This can get annoying at times if you're trying to get close to the edge of a platform without wanting to go up on it.

The second problem is that the difficulty is inconsistent.  I played on hard and while I found the very beginning to be sufficiently difficult, it got easier from there, especially once you get the first 2-3 health upgrades pretty quickly.  Some areas are overabundant in health pickups & killing enemies gives you a little health back as well.  Save points recover all missing health.  There's occasionally an area or two where the difficulty spikes for a little, but not too often.  Once you learn the basics of enemies, they'll usually give you little problems.   Later on, you can usually just run by enemies and mostly ignore them.  Bosses also suffer from the same problem.  There're 2-3 that are pretty tough and will probably kill you a time or two until you learn from your mistakes and win, but others are incomprehensibly easy.  The Pooh Sisters will barely put up a struggle and will probably only take down a fraction of your health before you slaughter them.  I beat both the final boss and his alternate form without dying once, and I arrived at the final boss with only about 40% of my total health.

The game can get a touch repetitive as you'll be fighting most of the same enemies throughout with occasional palette swaps which grant them different health/damage/special abilities/weaknesses/etc.  Would've been nice to have more enemy variety, though enemies do use different weaponry (Rifles, Snipers, Shotguns, Rockets, Machine guns, etc) which do make fights feel different.

You don't unlock the quick travel points until about 60-70% of the way through the game and the most that any one area will have is 1.  Some areas don't have any.  This can make backtracking for upgrades/pickups a little annoying later on when you've got all the special abilities.  Especially since some areas are relatively sizable and could take 5+ minutes to run through.  Most 'essential' stuff is usually somewhere close by where you find a new special ability.  It's usually only the unlockable art/intel/character info that are far off somewhere, so it'll only be really annoying for people trying to 100% the game.

Graphics are fine, music is hit and miss but is decent enough for the most part.  Didn't run into any bugs/crashes at any point.  Most of the games problems are minor points, though I would have really liked the game to be much more challenging, especially the bosses.  It's a solid entertaining game.

30477865.review:
Above all else, this is a game for anyone who gets a kick out of precise controls - assuming you have a decent controller to hand. Strider's signature katana arc is in full evidence here, allowing you to let loose a pleasing flurry of attacks or charge up for a longer-range strike. Movement includes an array of somersault jumps and combine with a wall-climbing mechanic that is never too clingy (as such mechanics can sometimes be). Basically, every room of enemies can be a fun, adrenaline-filled dance - and this is just with the basic toolset the game starts with.

There's some interesting depth here - you not only get ranged kunai attacks, a short teleporter hop and three extra modes for your sword, but each of these get different effects in combination, giving you plenty of high-energy options to take down even bigger foes with finesse. There's also a chain-based higher damage mode you can get to if you score a high succession of hits - I never popped the achievement for doing this 25 times, but I managed to quickly take down the one boss I had any real trouble by trigging a succession of these, and like everything else in this game's combat, it has the capacity to make you feel like the ultra-badass you probably aren't.

Elsewhere, the game can be unexceptional, though not in any significantly detrimental way. This Strider goes full Metroidvania, and while the aforementioned puzzles are great to track down, it lacks the clever item placement of something like Super Metroid (and for better or worse, there's nothing like that game's shine sparking to test your skills/patience). The environments are thoughtfully if visually unspectacular in their construction - though gameplay is on a 2D plane they've done a great job of layering things in the background and foreground, but it can all look a little samey and the series' distinctive cyber-soviet environments seem a little low-key this time round.

Enemy design is a similar story - in terms of function they've nailed it (on sight you have a good idea how an encounter is going to go down, and attacks are appropriately telegraphed so you can get on with the business of dodging and obliterating) but the designs don't really stick in your memory. Bosses are a little better on this front, though they're ultimately lifted from earlier games (and they have some over-used chatter before you encounter them).

Still, unless you've recently burned yourself out on Metroidvania-esque titles, there's more than enough style and substance in this game. I've owed this one a review for three years now - taken me around this time to actually have a machine that can run it (oddly) - Chris covered for me on thereticule (http://thereticule.com/strider-the-verdict/), but I couldn't resist singing it's praises myself, especially as three years on, it seems to have largely been forgotten. A shame.

30194516.review:
[b]Strider is a good action game, but a lame Metroidvania. [/b]

Strider is a reboot of... well, the Strider franchise. Strider was a dose of intense arcadey goodness, and when I heard it was rebooted as a Metroidvania, I was pretty surprised, but ready to give it a chance.

On the side of action, the game succeeds. Unfortunately, there's not a lot I can say that speaks to this. It feels as flashy and wild as it should. Bosses are frantic, enemies are dynamic, and the abilities you acquire are fun and empowering, kunais, dashes, new blade types, etc. My only real complaints here are that at the occasional gravity warping sections within the game, you never feel quite as in control as you should, and that switiching blade types on the fly can feel stressful. Oh, and turning around is kind of weird? But anyway. Graphically, it's exactly what it should be, throwbacks to the old games show up in proper spaces, but also aren't carbon copies. The soundtrack is actually really sick, unfortunately it is turned down too low to appreciate, like a lot of soundtracks nowadays. I recommend cranking it up a little! But otherwise, the combat is nice, the presentation works. Playtime is around five hours, and that's just about the right length. It all checks out.

But then we get to the fact that, again, this game is a Metroidvania. That means backtracking to get collectibles with new found power ups. But the issue with Strider's layout is that backtracking is genuinely annoying to go through. There are only a few warp points in the game, and they are far out of the way from the "Plaza" (the place you consistently return to over the game). The collectibles, too, are almost never worth going to get, with the exception of a few upgrades to your health and mechanical upgrades. Furthermore, rather than in a, well, GOOD Metroidvania, you aren't led silently to where you need to go to next by map design and the designer's invisible hand. You're given a waypoint on the map to head to. What was the point of making this a Metroidvania, then? If the areas were stacked in order, the game would have felt relatively the same, though a bit funky to backtrack through small parts of areas. I often feel compelled to collect everything I can in games like this, but in Strider, I just didn't bother. They're not hard to get, usually, theyre just not worth it. I didn't want to waste my time.

That being said, Strider is still a fun game. The action is frenetic and fun, but I'm honestly hesitant to recommend it. I actually felt like it wasted my time often when playing it. This is one of those many times I wish I could give a middling review score rather than the binary of "Yes" or "No". It's a good action game, but whenever it tries to be like a Metroid game, it just becomes boring. Buy at your own discretion.
